questions.text: Which of the following is considered as an absolute contraindication for Radioactive Iodine (RAI) ablation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lactation:

  • Lactation is an absolute contraindication for radioactive iodine (RAI) ablation. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Smoking, Young age, and Ophthalmopathy are relative contraindications of RAI ablation.

questions.text: For which procedures can Nonoperating room anesthesia (NORA) be used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - All are correct:

  • NORA - Non-operating Room Anaesthesia
    • Anaesthesia delivery in nonoperating room anaesthesia (NORA) settings should be held with the same high-quality standards as the operating room.
    • Nonoperating room anaesthesia refers to anaesthesia provided at locations remote from the operating room, like endoscopy, MRI suits, and natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery.
    • The procedure does not occur in the standard operation theatre; the operator is generally a medical interventionist. The procedures and technologies used are constantly evolving.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Angioplasty:

  • Angioplasty is included in the nonoperating room anaesthesia.
  • Other cardiac procedures are embolization and catheterization

Option B - MRI:

  • MRI is included in the NORA.
  • Other than MRI, CT scans and PET scans are other procedures

Option C - Endoscopy:

  • Extracorporeal Shockwave lithotripsy (ECWL) is one of the procedures that is a part of NORA.
  • Other processes involved are intubation processes and colonoscopy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with pain and tingling in her right arm, along with weakness in flexion at the elbow joint and hand grip. These symptoms began two weeks ago, and she has had severe difficulty getting dressed for the past three days. Which nerve roots innervate the affected muscles?
questions.solution:
Option C: C5, C6

  • Flexion of the arm at the elbow joint is done by the flexor muscles, which include biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis. All these flexors share the same innervation via musculocutaneous nerve with nerve roots C5 and C6.
  • The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the brachial plexus (C5 & C6 nerve roots).
  • The musculocutaneous nerve arises from the lateral cord and supplies the flexors of the arm.

MUSCLE

INNERVATION

ACTION

Biceps brachii

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5,C6)

Flexes and supinates the arm

Brachialis

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6)

Flexes the forearm in all positions

Coracobrachialis

Musculocutaneous nerve (C5,C6)

Flexes and adducts the arm at shoulder joint

Incorrect Options:

Option A: C8, T1

  • Nerve roots C8 and T1 combine to form an inferior trunk which gives the ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve courses medially in the forearm and supplies the flexors of the hands and digits.
  • These nerve roots do not participate in the formation of the musculocutaneous nerve.

Option B: T2, T3

  • Thoracic nerve T1 takes part in the formation of the brachial plexus.
  • However, from T2 onwards, these nerves supply the skin of the chest and intrinsic back muscles.
  • T2 and T3 do not supply the flexors of the upper limb.

Option D: C6,C7,C8

  • Nerve roots C6, C7, and C8 combine to form the radial nerve.
  • Radial nerve supplies
    • In radial groove - Triceps and Anconeus
    • Out of radial groove - Brachioradialis and Extensor carpi radialis longus
    • By deep motor branch - Extensor muscles of forearm and digits

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman came to the clinic with complaints of fever and cough with expectation for 4 days. On examination, her vitals were normal. The doctor advised Sputum AFB and the result was positive. Which of the following is the diagnosis of the condition mentioned here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tuberculosis:

  • The condition mentioned in the scenario is Tuberculosis
  • Tuberculosis is characterized by fever, cough with expectoration
  • Sputum AFB is positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • The preferred initial treatment regimen is INH, rifampin (RIF), and ethambutol (EMB) daily for 2 months, followed by INH and RIF daily, or twice weekly for 7 months (for a total of 9 months of treatment).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia is characterized by fever, cough with expectoration
  • AFB stain is not positive in Pneumonia

Option C -Viral fever:

  • AFB stain is not positive in Pneumonia

Option D - COVID-19:

  • AFB stain is not positive for COVID-19

questions.text: Identify the conditions using the images shown below and choose the appropriate target and drug that can be used for both.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ustekinumab and IL-12,23:

  • The first image shows the white, scaly appearance of the skin, which is seen in psoriasis.
  • The second image shows the cobblestone appearance of the intestinal lumen which helps in the diagnosis of Chron’s disease.
  • Ustekinumab is the monoclonal antibody that targets IL-12,23 and is used in the treatment of both the above conditions.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A and B - They are used in managing psoriasis cases alone and not in Inflammatory bowel disease.

Option C - Guselkumab and CD 2: Guselkumab acts on the target IL-23 and not CD 2

questions.text:
A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation undergoes a routine ultrasound examination. Ultrasound shows:



What is the interpretation of the given finding in a 12-week pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Dichorionic diamniotic twins:

  • Dichorionic diamniotic twins have separate chorions and amniotic sacs. USG shows the lambda or twin peak sign, which refers to a triangular or V-shaped thickened chorion insinuating between the two amniotic membranes. This sign is characteristic of dichorionic diamniotic twins.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Monochorionic monoamniotic twins:

  • Monochorionic monoamniotic twins share both the chorion and the amniotic sac. This condition is associated with a single thin membrane between the fetuses.

Option C - Monochorionic diamniotic twins:

  • Monochorionic diamniotic twins share a chorion but have separate amniotic sacs. They show T-sign. It is formed by the intersection of the decidua capsularis and the echogenic line representing the uterine cavity.

Option D - Conjoined twins:

  • The Lambda sign is not seen in conjoined twins.

questions.text: Which of the following features is true about feigned insanity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Exaggerated facial appearance: 

  • In cases of feigned insanity, the person voluntarily exaggerates the facial appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gradual onset: In feigned insanity, its Sudden onset.

Option B - Presence of predisposing factor: Predisposing factors are absent in feigned insanity.

Option D - Motive is usually absent: In feigned insanity, Motive is always present.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements and choose the appropriate answer.

Statement 1: Migraine can be challenging to diagnose, as the classic migraine aura is reported in only 20–25% of patients.

Statement 2: Visual disturbances, such as flashing lights or zigzag lines moving across the visual field, are common during the aura phase.

choices.text: Statements 1 and 2 are true and 2 is an adequate explanation to 1.
Statement 1 is false and 2 is true

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Statements 1 and 2 are true independently:

  • Statement 1: The statement accurately reflects the diagnostic challenge associated with migraine due to the variability in aura presentation.
  • Statement 2: The statement accurately describes the hallmark symptoms of migraine aura.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Guess the leading cause of death in Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy.

choices.text: Congestive heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congestive heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy:

  • The leading cause of death in Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy is congestive heart failure due to dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Pneumonia and Respiratory failures are the other leading causes of death in Duchenne's Muscular Dystrophy.

Incorrect Options

Options A, C, D:

  • These are not the leading causes of death in Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for the condition depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Antiviral drugs with steroids: 

  • The given image shows characteristic appearance seen in Ramsay Hunt syndrome(like vesical in concha area). The standard treatment for Ramsey-Hunt Syndrome involves antiviral drugs along with steroids.
     

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Surgical Decompression: This condition is due to viral infection, and the focus should be on antiviral therapy along with steroids, not surgical decompression.

Option C - Topical Antibiotics: Topical antibiotics are not the recommended treatment for viral infections like Ramsay Hunt Syndrome.

Option D - Supportive management: The primary treatment for Ramsay Hunt Syndrome involves antiviral drugs with steroids, not supportive treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with burning in the mid-epigastric region, a sour taste in his mouth after meals, and a red tongue-like mucosa observed during endoscopy with biopsy showing columnar metaplasia. At what distance from the gastroesophageal junction is the Z line seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: 5 cm

  • The above given is a case of Barret's esophagus.
  • The mid-epigastric burning pain + sour taste is a classic symptom.
  • Z-Line:
    • Zig–zag line.
    • Squamous columnar junction at lower 2 cm of the esophagus.
    • The lower 2cm of the esophagus is lined by columnar epithelium.
    • Prone to metaplasia/ dysplasia.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • The biopsy findings of columnar metaplasia and red mucosa on endoscopy confirm the diagnosis.

Option A: 2 cm

  • In normal individuals, the zig-zag line is located 2cm above the gastroesophageal junction.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option B: 3 cm

  • Squamous columnar junction at lower 2 cm of the esophagus.
  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction.

Option C: 4 cm

  • Barrett's esophagus: 5cm above the gastroesophageal junction, not 4cm.

questions.text: What genetic constitution is associated with the given histological findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A-/-- :

  • The genetic constitution A-/-- is associated with the formation of golf ball appearances in the red blood cells. In this condition, there is a decreased production of alpha-globin chains, resulting in excess beta-globin chains. These excess beta chains form unstable tetramers, leading to the characteristic golf ball appearance in the red blood cells.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D do not lead to the formation of golf ball appearances.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 3rd month post partum came to the clinic with complaints of sleeplessness, anxiety, low self worth for a week. She informed the consultant that she was unable to care for or bond with the baby. Which of the following is the diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Postpartum depression:

  • The condition mentioned in the scenario is Postpartum depression
  • This occurs within first 3-6 months
  • Characterized by insomnia, anxiety, low self worth
  • The woman is unable to care for or bond with the baby and is associated with excessive guilt and suicidal tendencies
  • This usually follows a prolonged course

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sheehan’s syndrome:

  • It is characterized by breastfeeding difficulty in the postpartum period
  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis occurs usually due to torrential hemorrhage during pregnancy or childbirth as the pituitary is very sensitive to hypoxia
  • This leads to lactational failure as well as global reduction in production of pituitary hormones

Option C - Postpartum psychosis:

  • This occurs in first 2-3 weeks (<1%)
  • Characterized by severe insomnia, rapid mood swings, psychomotor restlessness, delusions, hallucinations and is associated with cognitive impairment
  • This usually presents as a psychiatric emergency

Option D - Postpartum blues:

  • These occur within first few days and resolve by 2 weeks
  • 50-60% of patients may have this
  • Primarily due to withdrawal of progesterone
  • Characterized by
    • Mild mood swings
    • Irritability
    • Anxiety
    • Decreased concentration
    • Does not want to take care of child or becomes overprotective
    • Insomnia
    • Crying spells

questions.text: Using the image below, choose the odd immune checkpoint inhibitor that does not work on the same receptor as others.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ipilimumab:

  • Ipilimumab acts and blocks the CTLA-4 receptor of WBCs so that the B-7 antigen can't act on it thereby preventing it from destroying the cancer cells

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and D are all immune checkpoint inhibitors that act on PD-1 receptors on WBCs and block them.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient, 6 months post-renal transplantation, presents with fever, malaise, and fatigue. History includes recurrent urinary tract infections pre-transplant. Currently on immunosuppressive therapy. Lab findings: decreased WBC count, elevated liver enzymes, and "decoy cells" in urine microscopy. Which virus could potentially complicate transplant recipients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - BK Virus (BKV):

  • The patient's presentation with fever, malaise, fatigue, decreased white blood cell count, elevated liver enzymes, and the presence of "decoy cells" in urine microscopy, along with a history of renal transplantation and immunosuppressive therapy, is suggestive of a post-transplant viral infection. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a well-known organism in transplant recipients due to its ability to reactivate under immunosuppressed conditions.
  • BK virus (BKV) belongs to the Polyomavirus family, similar to CMV. BKV is associated with post-transplant complications, causing BK virus-associated nephropathy (BKVAN) in those with significant immunosuppression. The presence of "decoy cells" in urine microscopy is indicative of BKV infection.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV): Herpes Simplex Virus belongs to the Herpesviridae family. HSV can cause oral and genital lesions, encephalitis, and disseminated infection in immunocompromised individuals, but it is not specifically associated with "decoy cells" in urine microscopy or the same pattern of complications seen with BK virus.

Option B - Hepatitis B Virus (HBV): Hepatitis B Virus is a member of the Hepadnaviridae family. HBV primarily affects the liver, causing hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. It does not typically cause the renal complications and "decoy cell" formation seen with BK virus.

Option C - Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV): Varicella-Zoster Virus is another member of the Herpesviridae family. While VZV can reactivate in immunocompromised individuals, it manifests as shingles due to reactivation of the latent varicella zoster virus characterized by a rashes that is unilateral and confined to a single dermatome. The rash appears in multiple crops.

questions.text: Which of the following best sterilizes heat labile liquids like ASV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Membrane filters:

  • Heat-sensitive liquids like serum, vaccines, antisera, enzymes, antibiotics, and urea can be sterilized using the filtration method.
  • There are 2 types of filters:
    1. Depth filters: These are candle filters, Seitz filters (made of asbestos sheets, not used now), and glass filters.
    2. Membrane filters: Made of cellulose acetate and cellulose nitrate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dry heat:

  • Dry heat sterilization uses hot air from water vapor, killing the heat-sensitive material; hence, it is not used.

Option B - Autoclave:

  • This process is used to sterilize the medical grounds and stainless-steel instruments using steam denaturing the proteins and enzymes.

Option D - Pasteurization:

  • Pasteurization is a process of heat treatment that kills or inactivates harmful microorganisms in food and beverages.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the OPD by his mother due to concerns of hearing loss. Upon examination, the pediatrician noticed jaundice, microcephaly, and hepatomegaly. After a thorough evaluation, a diagnosis is made, and ganciclovir is prescribed for the child. What is the risk of acquiring this condition during the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 25%:

There is a 25% chances of acquiring CMV in 2nd trimester.

  • 90% of the infected babies with CMV (Cytomegalovirus) are asymptomatic
  • Symptomatic infants present with:
    • Microcephaly
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Jaundice
    • Petechiae
    • Most important long-term sequelae of congenital CMV infection: Sensorineural hearing loss
    • It is treated with Ganciclovir

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 15%:

  • This is the risk of getting Congenital toxoplasmosis in first-trimester

Option C - 60%:

  • This is the risk of getting Congenital toxoplasmosis in third-trimester

Option D - 55%:

  • This does not indicate risk of getting Congenital toxoplasmosis in second-trimester

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is diagnosed with an exotropia that is more noticeable when he looks downward than upward. Which of the following patterns is most likely associated with his squint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – A pattern:

  • According to the question the child is suffering from exotropia, which is more on a down gaze then, it is A pattern squint.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – V pattern: Exotropia more on down gaze is an A pattern, whereas when exotropia is more in up gaze then it is a V pattern.

Option C – No pattern squint: No pattern squint implies that there is no specific pattern of convergence noted. However, in this case, the presence of a more noticeable exotropia when looking downward suggests a pattern squint.

Option D – Cannot be determined: Given the specific information provided about the exotropia being more noticeable when looking downward, it is possible to determine that a pattern squint is present.

questions.text: This rave party drug, an indirectly acting adrenergic drug, has a great ability to cross BBB and has less action in peripheral organs. Following are the triad of this poisoning, except.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stroke:

  • The drug mentioned in the question is Amphetamine.
  • Stroke is not present in the triad of Amphetamine poisoning.
  • Amphetamine, an indirectly acting adrenergic drug, has a great ability to cross BBB and has less action in peripheral organs.
  • Used in the treatment of ADHD.
  • Triad of Amphetamine poisoning:
    • Sudden psychosis
    • Hypertension
    • Golden color urine
    • DOC for amphetamine poisoning is Ammonium chloride.
  • This is performance-enhancing drugs.
    • Students abuse this drug.
    • Young people abuse these drugs while partying. Hence, they are called rave party drugs.
    • Abused by sportsmen (Dope test is done)

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C, D: These symptoms are the triad of Amphetamine poisoning.

questions.text: In a community medicine study assessing the efficacy of a new vaccination program, researchers aim to determine if the program reduces the incidence of a specific infectious disease in a population. They set the significance level (α) at 0.05. During analysis, they discover a statistically significant decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals compared to the control group. However, upon further investigation, it is found that the decrease in disease incidence is not actually attributable to the vaccination program. Which of the following is not true about Type 1 error?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but rejected

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The null hypothesis is false but rejected:

  • The correct statement would be: “The null hypothesis is true but rejected.”
  • Type 1 error means stating that there is an effect or difference when none exists (H0 incorrectly rejected in favor of H1).

 

Reality

H1

H0

Study rejects H0

Power (1-β)

Type 1 error (α)

Study does not reject H0

Type 2 error (β)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - α error:

  • α error refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true. In this case, the researchers set the significance level (α) at 0.05, indicating the threshold for accepting or rejecting the null hypothesis. Therefore, α error is related to this scenario.

Option B - False positive trial:

  • A false positive trial occurs when the intervention appears effective, but in reality, it does not have the intended effect. In this scenario, the apparent decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals constitutes a false positive result because the vaccination program is not the cause of the observed reduction.

Option C - Serious error:

  • Type 1 is a serious error in hypothesis testing as it can lead to incorrect conclusions and potentially harmful decisions, such as implementing an ineffective intervention or treatment.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a complaint of passing dark-colored urine and back pain for the past month. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the right costovertebral angle. His urine analysis report is shown below. Urine microscopic analysis reveals many RBCs, few WBCs, and no casts or crystals. The kidney lesion's typical gross appearance is depicted in the figure. Which one of the following components in this man's blood is most likely to be elevated

Urine Analysis Report


	
		
			
			pH
			
			
			6
			
		
		
			
			Specific Gravity
			
			
			1.015
			
		
		
			
			Hematuria
			
			
			2+
			
		
		
			
			Protein
			
			
			Nill
			
		
		
			
			Glucose
			
			
			Nill
			
		
		
			
			Ketones
			
			
			Nill
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Erythropoietin:

  • The figure demonstrates renal cell carcinoma. In between 5% and 10% of these tumours, erythropoietin is secreted, resulting in polycythemia.
  • Erythropoietin production by renal cell carcinoma cells and cyst epithelial cells in the left kidney may cause polycythemia.
  • Serum urea nitrogen and creatinine levels are not raised, and renal function is not significantly lost since renal cell carcinomas are frequently unilateral and do not completely kill a kidney.
  • Erythropoietin is a glycoprotein produced mainly by the kidney and controls erythropoiesis. Increased erythropoiesis production results in secondary erythrocytosis, which is observed in various tumours, including renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, and cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
  • The lack of erythrocytosis in renal cell carcinoma patients with elevated erythropoietin levels may be explained by the possibility that renal cell carcinoma cells create an inactive isoform of erythropoietin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Globulin:

  • Globulin would be increased with multiple myeloma and lead to amyloid deposition, a diffuse process.
  • Increased gamma globulin proteins may indicate any acute infection

Option B - Cortisol:

  • Corticotropin (adrenocorticotropic hormone) results in hypercortisolism in Cushing syndrome, but these cases are encountered less frequently than polycythemia. 
  • Cushing's disease can manifest as secondary polycythemia, and polycythemia can be the first sign of Cushing's disease.

Option D - Vasopressin:

  • A syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (vasopressin) is more likely a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with small-cell lung carcinomas.
  • Vasopressin also has a potent constricting effect on arterioles throughout the body

questions.text: A 32-year-old who died after a traumatic brain injury is diagnosed with diffuse axonal injury. When does this patient's earliest histological evidence first appear?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 12 hours:

  • The earliest histological/microscopic evidence for the diagnosis of diffuse axonal injury is 'retraction balls” which appear 12-18 hours after injury.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D do not match the time frame for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with recurrent intermittent chest pain at rest, accompanied by episodes of dysphagia. An ECG is normal. Patient undergoes barium swallow. Which of the following is correct about the diagnosis and findings seen in this condition?

choices.text: Barium swallow shows irregular narrowing of lower esophagus, suggesting stricture formation
Smooth and symmetric narrowing of the esophagus, consistent with diagnosis of esophageal diverticulum
Corkscrew or Rosary bead appearance is consistent with the diagnosis of diffuse esophageal spasm
Dilated esophagus with impaired peristalsis, resembling a "bird's beak" appearance

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Corkscrew or Rosary bead appearance is consistent with the diagnosis of diffuse esophageal spasm:

  • Diffuse esophageal spasm is associated with abnormal, uncoordinated contractions of the esophageal muscles, leading to a corkscrew or Rosary bead appearance on a barium swallow study.
  • This distinctive radiographic finding results from the simultaneous, high-amplitude contractions of the esophageal wall. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Barium swallow shows irregular narrowing of the lower esophagus, suggesting stricture formation: Narrowing at the lower esophagus is suggestive of stricture formation.

Option B - Smooth and symmetric narrowing of the esophagus, consistent with diagnosis of esophageal diverticulum: This description is suggestive of conditions such as achalasia or esophageal diverticula.

Option D - Dilated esophagus with impaired peristalsis, resembling a "bird's beak" appearance: Dilated esophagus with impaired peristalsis, resembling a "bird's beak" appearance, is more indicative of achalasia.

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset weakness of both lower limbs. On examination, she has flaccid paralysis without any sensory deficits. Considering the clinical presentation, which of the following age groups is associated with acute flaccid paralysis?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - 0-15 years

  • Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) is characterized by the sudden onset of weakness or loss of muscle tone and reflexes in one or more limbs.
  • It can be caused by various infectious agents, including poliovirus, enteroviruses, and other pathogens.
  • In the context of the scenario described, where a girl presents with sudden onset weakness of both lower limbs, acute flaccid paralysis should be considered.
  • This condition is seen in children under the age of 15, with the highest incidence typically occurring in children under 5 years old.

 

Incorrect options: B,C,D

questions.text:
Below are images of different types of surgical knots. Match them with their corresponding names. 


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			a. Granny knot
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. Square knot
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c. Surgeon's knot
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 1-c, 2-a, 3-b:

  • Surgeon’s knot: It consists of two throws. There are two wraps in the first throw and one in the second, and crossing occurs in each throw.
  • Granny knot: This knot, also called a pseudo square knot, involves two throws taken without crossing. One end is above, and the other is below. The granny knot is more prone to slip and is relatively unstable.
  • Square knot: This knot, also known as the reef knot, consists of two throws, and crossing is done in each throw. It is relatively secure.

questions.text: A newborn develops yellowish discolouration of skin which is more towards the limbs compared to the face. On evaluation, the bilirubin level on soles is 14 mg/dl while on the face, it is 6 mg/dl. Which part of the brain is commonly involved in neonatal jaundice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Basal Ganglia

  • Most Commonly involved part of the brain in neonatal jaundice: Basal ganglia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Thalamus

Option B - Hypothalamus

Option C -  Lateral ventricle

  • These are not commonly involved in neonatal jaundice

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man who has been studying the ecological changes at Mount Everest base camp for the past 2 weeks gets a blood gas analysis done. His ABG analysis shows:

pH = 7.51

PCO2 = 25 mmHg

HCO3 = 19 mEq/L

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: D - Partially compensated respiratory alkalosis

ABG - Normal parameters:

  • pH: 7.35-7.45
  • PaO2: 60 - 100 mmHg
  • PaCO2: 35 - 45 mmHg
  • HCO3: 22 to 26 mEq/L

In this question:

  • pH: 7.51 = Alkalosis
  • PaCO2 = 25 mmHg = Decreased
  • HCO3 = 19 mEq/L = Decreased - Compensation is taking place

This is a case of acclimitization. Exposure to high altitudes causes chronic hyperventilation due to low PO2 at high altitudes. Hyperventilation causes CO2 washout and respiratory alkalosis. A few days later, renal compensation starts taking place, and there will be compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents to the OPD with a painless swelling below the inner corner of the right eye that has been present since birth. On examination, a bluish cystic mass is noted, and gentle pressure causes regurgitation of mucoid material. What embryological structure is involved in the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Imperforated Hasner Valve:

  • This clinical presentation is indicative of a congenital dacryocele, where there is dilation of the lacrimal sac due to an imperforated Hasner valve. The Hasner valve is a membrane at the inferior end of the nasolacrimal duct, and an imperforated valve can result in the retention of amniotic fluid mucus trapping in the lacrimal sac.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Failure of nasolacrimal duct canalization:

  • Failure of nasolacrimal duct canalization typically leads to nasolacrimal duct obstruction and epiphora, not a bluish cystic mass.

Option B - Abnormal lacrimal puncta formation:

  • Lacrimal puncta are responsible for draining tears into the nasolacrimal duct, and abnormal formation could contribute to tear drainage issues, but it doesn't directly match the described presentation.

Option D - Aberrant lacrimal gland development:

  • Aberrant lacrimal gland development is not typically associated with the described presentation of a bluish cystic mass below the inner corner of the eye with mucoid material regurgitation.

questions.text: The given graph is a Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate regarding group 2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Shorter survival without screening test:

  • Kaplan-Meier Survival Analysis estimates the probability of survival over time based on observational data, providing visual survival curves. Complications arise from dropout rates, impacting survival estimation.
  • Plotting: Survival curves are plotted to visualize the analysis, showing the probability of survival over time for different groups.
  • Group Comparison: In this case, Group 1 represents patients with longer survival who received a screening test, while Group 2 represents patients with shorter survival who did not receive the screening test.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect due to the above-given reason.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 50-year-old woman presenting with fatigue, dyspnea, left atrial enlargement, mitral valve calcification, and a CT scan revealing a large left atrial mass, who subsequently dies of an ischemic stroke before open heart surgery, with the given autopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cardiac Myxoma:

  • Myxomas are the most common primary tumour of the heart. Most myxomas occur in the left atrium but can happen in any chamber or valve.

  • These tumours appear as a glistening, gelatinous polypoid mass, usually 6 to 7 cm in diameter, Unlike a mural thrombus.

  • The causes of Myxoma can be genetic or sporadic. Genetic causes are due to activating mutations in the GNAS1 gene that encodes the alpha unit of the G protein.

  • Clinical manifestations of the Myxoma are due to ball valve obstruction of the valve. It can also present with a syndrome of constitutional symptoms such as fever and malaise. Although the tumour does not metastasize, it may embolize.

  • The constitutional symptoms are due to the release of a cytokine, Interleukin – 6, from the Myxoma.

  • More than half the patients have evidence of mitral valve dysfunction, which can progress to left heart failure.

  • Microscopically, Myxoma has a loose myxoid stroma containing abundant proteoglycans.

  • Diagnosis of the tumour can be made using an echocardiogram. Further imaging, such as CT or MRI, can help to characterize better and identify cancer.

  • Most myxomas are benign, and Surgery is usually the treatment of choice.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Calcific aortic stenosis:

  • Calcific aortic stenosis involves calcifying the aortic valve due to wear and tear or congenital bicuspid aortic valve. The image given above demonstrated atrial Myxoma and not calcific aortic stenosis.

Option C - Fibroelastoma:

  • Fibroelastoma is a benign primary tumour of the heart. However, the image given above demonstrated atrial Myxoma.

Option D - Mural thrombus:

  • The image demonstrates a glistening, gelatinous polypoid mass seen in an atrial myxoma, unlike a mural thrombus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of joint pain and swelling in his right big toe. He describes the pain as sudden and excruciating, often waking him up at night. On examination, the affected joint is warm, erythematous, and tender on palpation. Based on the clinical presentation and the X-ray image shown below, what is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Gout with monosodium urate crystal deposition

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Gout with monosodium urate crystal deposition:

  • The "Martel sign" is a radiographic finding associated with gout, a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of urate crystals in the joints.
  • In gout, the Martel sign refers to the appearance of a sharply outlined triangular or V-shaped opacity adjacent to the bone cortex at the joint margin, typically seen on X-rays of affected joints.
  • This sign is most commonly observed in the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe), a common site of gouty arthritis. The triangular opacity represents the deposition of urate crystals within the soft tissues adjacent to the bone. 
  • The presence of the Martel sign on X-ray, along with clinical symptoms and other imaging findings, can help diagnose gout.
  • However, it is important to note that the absence of the Martel sign does not exclude the diagnosis of gout, as it may not always be present or visible in all cases.
  • Other imaging modalities, such as ultrasound or MRI, can also aid in the diagnosis of gout and may reveal findings not seen on X-ray.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Osteoarthritis with tophi formation: Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage, while tophi formation is typically seen in gout.

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis with joint erosions: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that primarily affects the joints, but it is characterized by symmetrical joint involvement and specific rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody testing. Joint erosions are a hallmark feature of rheumatoid arthritis, but they are not specific to gout.

Option D - Septic arthritis with joint effusion: Septic arthritis is an infection of the joint caused by bacteria or other pathogens. It typically presents with a hot, swollen, and acutely painful joint, along with systemic signs of infection. Joint effusion (fluid accumulation) is a common feature, but it is not specific to gout.

questions.text: The histopathological image shown below represents a dermatological condition. Identify the key feature observed in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Acantholysis:

  • Acantholysis refers to the loss of intercellular connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis, resulting in the separation of these cells. In the provided histopathological image, the presence of acantholysis is indicated by the detachment of keratinocytes from each other, leading to the formation of spaces or clefts between the cells. Moreover, a distinctive feature observed in this image is the presence of a row of tombstone cells. Tombstone cells are keratinocytes that remain attached to the basement membrane while the neighboring cells have detached, creating a row-like appearance. This characteristic pattern of acantholysis with tombstone cells is commonly associated with pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyperkeratosis: Hyperkeratosis refers to the thickening of the stratum corneum, the outermost layer of the epidermis, due to excessive accumulation of keratin. It is not the characteristic feature observed in the provided histopathological image, which primarily depicts acantholysis with a row of tombstone cells.

Option C - Epidermal hyperplasia: Epidermal hyperplasia refers to the abnormal thickening or increase in the number of cell layers in the epidermis. This is not the main feature depicted in the provided histopathological image, which primarily shows acantholysis with a row of tombstone cells.

Option D - Papillomatosis: Papillomatosis is characterized by the presence of finger-like projections or papillary structures extending from the epidermis into the underlying dermis. This feature is not observed in the provided histopathological image, which primarily showcases acantholysis with a row of tombstone cells.

questions.text: A 6-day-old male neonate presents to the paediatrics department with feeding difficulty and respiratory distress. He is born to a 22-year-old mother at a gestational age of 36 weeks with a low birth weight(2.2 kg). The mother complained of hyperemesis gravidarum in the first trimester, along with oligohydramnios. On examination, the neonate has micrognathia, a "U"-shaped cleft palate, and glossoptosis. What is the most likely diagnosis associated with cleft palate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pierre Robin Sequence:

  • Pierre Robin syndrome (PRS) is a congenital condition in which the infant has:
    • Micrognathia (small jaw)
    • Glossoptosis (a tongue that falls back toward the throat)
    • Upper airway obstruction. 
  • Infants with the condition also commonly have a cleft palate.
  • Although most lip and palate clefts occur as an isolated deformity, Pierre Robin Sequence remains the most common syndrome.
  • The most common symptoms may include the following:
    • An underdeveloped jaw 
    • A tongue that's more posteriorly positioned.
    • Snoring and airway obstruction
    • A high-arched palate
    • Cleft palate
    • Natal teeth 
    • Dysphagia 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Down Syndrome:

  • Down syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality caused by the presence of trisomy of chromosome 21.
  • A cleft palate can also be associated with infants born with down's syndrome.
  • Patients with downs syndrome present with the following:
    • Decreased muscle tone
    • Short neck
    • Flat face 
    • Small head, ears, and mouth
    • Upward slanting eyes
    • Epicanthal folds
    • Wide, short hands

Option B - Treacher-Collins' Syndrome:

  • Treacher-Collins syndrome is a condition that affects the development of:
    • Facial Bones
    • Tissues of the face
  • It is characterised by the following:
    • Underdeveloped facial bones
    • Micrognathia
    • Cleft palate
    • Eyelid coloboma
    • Hearing loss is caused by the underdevelopment of the ear canal

Option D - Spina Bifida:

  • Spina Bifida is a type of neural tube defect in which a part of the neural tube does not develop or close properly, leading to a defect in the spinal cord or the vertebrae of the fetus.
  • Folic acid deficiency is one of the known risk factors for neural tube defects.
  • Depending upon the type of defect, there are a few types of spina bifida:
    • Spina bifida occulta,
    • Meningocele
    • Myelomeningocele.
  • Spina bifida occulta is the most common and the mildest form of spina bifida in which there is a malformation of one or more vertebrae, leading to a small gap in the spine.
  • Meningocele is a serious type of spina bifida where the meninges covering the spinal cord are pushed out of the vertebrae.
  • Myelomeningocele is a severe type of spina bifida in which a portion of the spinal cord or nerves are pushed out of the vertebrae, which may or may not be covered with meninges.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman taking oral contraceptives presents with complaints of peripheral neuropathy, dry, scaly lips with cracks at the corner of the mouth. Blood examination reveals sideroblastic anemia. This patient's condition is caused by the deficiency of a vitamin that acts as a cofactor in which of the following steps of catecholamine synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C:

  • Clinical features such as peripheral neuropathy and sideroblastic anemia in a patient on OCPs point to Vitamin B6 deficiency.
  • DOPA decarboxylase requires pyridoxal phosphate, the active form of vitamin B6, for L-DOPA conversion.
  • Additionally, vitamin B6 acts as a cofactor in various reactions including cystathionine synthesis, heme synthesis, decarboxylation, and transamination.
  • Clinical signs of deficiency include glossitis, gingivostomatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and sideroblastic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A:

This is false because:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine in the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB).
  • Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

Option B - B:

This is false because:

  • Tyrosine hydroxylase catalyzes tyrosine's conversion to L-DOPA in the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin (THB).
  • Clinical features of THB deficiency include swallowing difficulty, behavioral problems, seizures, and progressive neurologic deterioration, which this patient lacks.

Option D - D:

This is false because:

  • Dopamine β-hydroxylase catalyzes the conversion of dopamine to norepinephrine in the presence of the cofactor's vitamin C (ascorbic acid) and Cu2+.
  • Clinical features of vitamin C deficiency include follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular bleeding, ecchymoses, gingivitis, and impaired wound healing, which are not observed here.
  • Moreover, most patients with vitamin C deficiency will have either normocytic anemia or macrocytic anemia unlike this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident presents with severe facial injuries and an inability to feel sensation on the tip of his nose. Which nerve injury is the most likely cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve
The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve:

  • The sensory ophthalmic division supplies the cornea, skin of the forehead, scalp, eyelids, nose, mucous membrane of the nose, the maxillary air sinus, and palate.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - The maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve:

  • Maxillary branch (V2) of the trigeminal nerve supplies skin, lower eyelid, and upper lip

Option C - Greater auricular nerve:

  • The greater auricular nerve (V3) supplies, the greater part of the auricle
  • Laterally
  • Medially (lobule) (medial upper part by the lesser auricular nerve)
  • Vagus supplies root

Option D - Mandibular nerve:

  • Mandibular branch (V3) supplies the skin of mandible except for the angle of mandible

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the pharmacokinetic property exhibited by thiopentone, contributing to its rapid onset and short duration of action during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Redistribution:
 

  • Thiopentone exhibits redistribution, which contributes to its rapid onset and short duration of action during anesthesia. Redistribution refers to the process where a drug initially distributes into highly perfused tissues, such as the brain, leading to a quick onset of action. However, it then redistributes from these tissues into less perfused tissues, particularly fat stores, causing a decrease in plasma concentration and termination of its action on the brain. This phenomenon results in the short duration of action of thiopentone.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zero-order kinetics:

  • Describes constant drug elimination rate regardless of concentration.
  • Thiopentone doesn't follow zero-order kinetics; it's eliminated via first-order kinetics.

Option B - First-pass metabolism:

  • Metabolism by the liver before systemic circulation, typically via portal vein.
  • Thiopentone is eliminated primarily via redistribution, not first-pass metabolism.

Option D - Renal clearance:

  • Involves drug elimination through kidneys.
  • Thiopentone is primarily eliminated via redistribution into fat tissues, not renal clearance.

questions.text: Which of the following are the cusps of the aortic valve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Posterior; left; right

  • There are three aortic valve cusps, each semilunar in appearance. Each cusp (sinus of Valsalva or aortic sinus) is associated with a small dilatation of the proximal aorta.
  • The three cusps are the left, right and posterior (or non-coronary). The cusps form small pockets with their mouths directed away from the ventricle cavity. Opposite the cusps, the aortic walls are slightly dilated to form the aortic sinus (left, right, and posterior sinus). In the normal human heart, the left and right coronary arteries originate from the left and right aortic sinuses, respectively.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Anterior; right; posterior

  • The three aortic valve cusps are right, left, and posterior, not anterior, right, and posterior.

Option C: Anterior; left; posterior

  • The three aortic valve cusps are the right, left and posterior, anterior and posterior.

Option D: Anterior; left; right

  • The three aortic valve cusps are the right, left, and posterior, not anterior, left, and right.

questions.text: The following graph indicates the clearance of which molecule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Inulin:

  • The graph shows the clearance of inulin, which is a substance that is only cleared from the blood by glomerular filtration and is neither secreted nor absorbed from the peritubular capillaries. Consequently, the inulin clearance rate remains constant and is irrespective of plasma concentration. As the concentration of inulin in plasma increases, so does its filtration rate, resulting in a constant ratio that is reflected in the graph.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D: The given graph doesnot match with clearance of PAH, creatinine and Glucose.

questions.text: A mother brought her 5-year-old boy to the emergency department complaining of stomach pain, watery diarrhoea, loss of appetite, and vomiting. The sample was sent to the laboratory for diagnosis. The causative organism showed effacement and attachment of intestinal cells, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - EPEC:

  • The above is infectious diarrhea by EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).
  • The organism that shows effacement and attachment of intestinal cells is EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli).

  • It is the major causative agent of infantile diarrhea in developing countries by attaching to enterocytes and causing their effacement.

  •  Initially localized adherence to enterocytes via type IV bundle-forming pili leads to a characteristic effacement of microvilli, with the formation of cuplike, actin-rich pedestals mediated by factors in the locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE).

Incorrect Option:

Option B - ETEC:

  • ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E.coli) causes attachment through CFA (colonization factor antigen).

Option C – EHEC:

  • EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E.coli) causes VT (verotoxin) mediated capillary microangiopathy.

Option D - V. Cholerae.:

  • Vibrio cholerae lives in contaminated water.
  • It enters the human body by the consumption of uncooked seafood (e.g., raw shellfish).
  • Vibrio cholera is a facultative anaerobe, oxidase-positive, and straight or curved (comma-shaped) bacteria.
  • It has a Polar flagellum.
  • It grows in alkaline media and requires a large infectious dose.
  • Cholera toxin (enterotoxin) is a protein that causes “rice-water” diarrhea.

questions.text: A stool examination of a patient shows the presence of an egg as given in image. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Praziquantel:

  • This is a case of Schistosoma (blood fluke) infection
  • DOC: Praziquantel
  • MOA: Calcium influx causing spastic muscle paralysis
  • Praziquantel is a drug of choice for all cestodes and trematodes
  • Contraindication in ocular cysticercosis as it causes eye inflammation leading to blindness.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Albendazole:

  • Albendazole is DOC for
    • Hydatid cyst (Echinococcus)
    • Neurocysticercosis
    • Ascariasis
    • Ancylostoma(Hookworm)
    • Enterobius(Pinworm)
    • Trichuris(Whipworm)
    • Trichinella(Pork worm)

Option C - Triclabendazole:

  • Triclabendazole is DOC for Fasciola hepatica(liver fluke).

Option D - Ivermectin:

  • Ivermectin is given in the treatment of Scabies, Strongyloides, Onchocerca volvulus.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Handicapped 
			
			
			A. Suffers from an accident and loses his body part
			
		
		
			
			2. Disability 
			
			
			B. Inability to fulfill his/her roles and responsibilities
			
		
		
			
			3. Impairment 
			
			
			C. Loss or abnormality of physiological, psychological function, or anatomical structure
			
		
		
			
			4. Health event 
			
			
			D. Restriction or inability to perform an activity
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A:

Disease/Health Event

  • A person suffers from an accident and loses his leg.

Impairment

  • Impairment means any loss or abnormality of physiological, psychological function, or anatomical structure.

  • Here, loss of leg is anatomical

Disability

  • Disability is restriction or inability to perform an activity.

  • The person cannot walk, this is a disability.

Handicapped

  • Handicapped is when someone cannot fulfill his roles and responsibilities.

  • As he cannot do work, he loses his job, this is handicapped.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department by his parents due to episodes of severe abdominal pain and inconsolable crying. The parents report that the child has been having episodes of drawing up his legs to his chest and passing currant jelly stool. On physical examination, a sausage-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The infant appears distressed, and his vital signs are stable. Abdominal ultrasound reveals a characteristic radiological sign given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Intussusception

  • Intussusception is a condition in which a segment of the intestine invaginates into the adjacent segment, leading to bowel obstruction. It commonly affects infants and presents with episodes of severe abdominal pain, drawing up of legs, and "currant jelly" stool (blood and mucus in the stool). On physical examination, a palpable sausage-shaped mass may be present. The radiological findings of the "donut sign" on abdominal ultrasound is characteristic of intussusception (it is also seen in IHPS). Barium enema shows a “claw sign.”USG shows target sign, sign of bowel within bowel

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gastroenteritis: Gastroenteritis refers to inflammation of the stomach and intestines, commonly caused by viral or bacterial infections. It presents with symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. It can cause abdominal discomfort.Target sign is not seen in gastroenteritis

Option B - Hirschsprung's disease: Hirschsprung's disease is a congenital condition characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the large intestine, leading to functional obstruction. It typically presents in the neonatal period with failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension. Zone of transition is seen in barium enema

The annotated image demonstrates the transition zone with a small caliber rectum and dilated sigmoid colon (rectosigmoid ratio less than 1.0). - second image

Option D - Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital outpouching of the small intestine located near the ileocecal valve. It is typically asymptomatic but can present with complications such as bleeding, intestinal obstruction, or inflammation. Meckel's diverticulum is seen on the antimesenteric side of the small intestine. It is considered a true diverticulum, as it contains all layers of the intestinal wall.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male came complaining of odynophagia. On endoscopy, shallow punched-out ulcers with a few vesicles are seen on the lower 1/3rd of the esophagus. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis :
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Herpes simplex esophagitis:

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection .
  • Endoscopic findings reveal shallow erosions or ulcers(punched-out lesions) and vesicles, typically involving the lower third of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CMV esophagitis:

  • CMV endoscopy would show deep ulcers, most commonly in the middle third of the esophagus.

Option B - Candida esophagitis:

  • Esophageal candidiasis Endoscopy would show white plaques on the esophageal mucosa.

Option C - Corrosive esophagitis:

  • Corrosive esophagitis is characterized by Esophageal bleeding, perforation, or stricture can be worsened by high-degree corrosive esophagitis.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Astrocytes
			
			
			A
			
			
			Formation of the myelin sheath in CNS
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Oligodendrocytes
			
			
			B
			
			
			Formation of Blood Brain Barrier (BBB)
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Ependymal cells
			
			
			C
			
			
			Formation of Cerebrospinal fluid
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-B, 2-A, 3-C:

  1. Astrocytes - Formation of Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB): Astrocytes are a type of glial cell in the central nervous system (CNS) that forms the blood-brain barrier (BBB). They form tight junctions with endothelial cells of the capillaries, regulating the passage of substances between the bloodstream and the brain.
  2. Oligodendrocytes - Formation of the myelin sheath in CNS: Oligodendrocytes are another type of glial cell in the CNS responsible for producing the myelin sheath, which wraps around axons of neurons. This myelin sheath serves to insulate the axons.
  3. Ependymal cells - Formation of Cerebrospinal fluid: Ependymal cells are involved in the production and circulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which cushions the brain and spinal cord, provides buoyancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: A child is brought to the clinic by his mother for routine evaluation. On examination, he is active and healthy. He copies a rectangle. What is the most likely age of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Four years:

  • A child copies a rectangle or a plus at 4 years

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Five years: Copies a triangle.

Option C - Three years: Copies a circle

Option D - Two years: Makes vertical and circular strokes.

questions.text: A patient presents with a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals. Which stage of syphilis does this presentation indicate, and what is the recommended medical treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary syphilis, Benzathine penicillin:

  • The presentation of a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders on the genitals is characteristic of primary syphilis. The recommended medical treatment for primary syphilis is Benzathine penicillin G (2.4 million units), which is administered as a single intramuscular injection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secondary syphilis, Doxycycline:

  • Secondary syphilis is characterized by a systemic rash and flu-like symptoms. Doxycycline is the preferred medication to treat cases with severe penicillin allergy.

Option C - Tertiary syphilis, Ceftriaxone:

  • Tertiary syphilis is the late stage of the disease, which occurs years after the initial infection. It is characterized by the development of severe complications, such as gummas (soft, non-cancerous growths), cardiovascular abnormalities, and neurosyphilis. The presentation of a single painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders is more typical of primary syphilis. Ceftriaxone is not the first-line treatment for primary syphilis, it is the preferred medication for neurosyphilis in cases of severe penicillin allergy

Option D - Congenital syphilis, Azithromycin:

  • Congenital syphilis occurs when a pregnant woman with syphilis passes the infection to her unborn child. The presentation described in the question is not indicative of congenital syphilis, as it refers to an ulcer on the genitals of the patient.

questions.text: What is most likely present at the site marked as C in the diagram of 1st rib given below?
questions.solution:
Option C: Scalenus anterior

  •  The site marked as C in the diagram shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle. The upper surface of the shaft of the first rib is crossed obliquely by two grooves separated by a ridge. The ridge is enlarged at the inner border of the rib to form a scalene tubercle. The anterior groove on the superior surface of the shaft lodges the subclavian vein(D), and the posterior groove lodges the subclavian artery(B) and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. Behind the groove for the subclavian artery is an elongated rough area where the middle scalene(A) inserts.
  • The anterior scalene muscle lies beneath the sternocleidomastoid muscle. It originates from the anterior tubercles of transverse processes of C3-C6 vertebrae and attaches to the scalene tubercle present on the medial side of the first rib. Its tendon is sandwiched between the subclavian vein (passing anteriorly) and subclavian artery (passing posteriorly). Both vessels cross over the superior surface of the 1st rib. It elevates the first rib, ipsilateral lateral flexion of the neck and bilateral anterior flexion of the neck and is innervated by the anterior rami of the C5 and C6 vertebrae. The interscalene block is given between the anterior and middle scalene muscles at the level of the cricoid cartilage.

Option D: Subclavian vein

  • The site marked as D shows the groove for the subclavian vein. It is an anterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

Option B: Subclavian artery

  • The site marked as B shows the groove for the subclavian artery. It is a posterior groove on the superior surface of the first rib. It lodges the subclavian artery and the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

Option A: Scalenus medius

  • The site marked as A shows an elongated rough area behind the groove for the subclavian artery. It is the site attachment of the middle scalene muscle. The site marked as C shows the scalene tubercle, which is the site of attachment of the anterior scalene muscle.

questions.text: A primigravida woman at 33 weeks of gestation is brought with his husband complaining of decreased fetal movements For assessment, the patient is advised a test by a device as in the image shown below. This device is used for which of the following assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B:

  • The above-shown device is NST. The nonstress test measures the fetal heart rate in response to fetal movement over time. The term "non-stress" means that during the test, nothing is done to place stress on the fetus. If two or more accelerations occur within 20 minutes, the result is considered reactive or "reassuring". A reactive result means that for now, it does not appear that there are any problems. A non-reactive result is one in which not enough accelerations are detected in 40 minutes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gestational age estimation is done by ultrasound.

Option C: Fetal arterial Doppler is done by Doppler ultrasonography.

Option D: Assessment of the progress of labor is done by serial abdominal and vaginal assessments and best plotted on a partograph.
