Below are various images of posterior hip dislocation. Match them with their appropriate classes.


	
		
			
			1)

			
			
			
			a) Pipkin class 4
			
		
		
			
			2)

			
			
			
			b) Thompson type 4
			
		
		
			
			3)

			
			
			
			c) Thompson type 1
			
		
		
			
			4)

			
			
			
			d) Pipkin class 3
			
		
		
			
			5)

			
			
			
			e) Pipkin class 2
			
		
		
			
			6)

			
			
			
			f) Thompson type 2
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			g) Pipkin class 1
			
		
		
			
			 
			
			
			e) Thompson type 3
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-c, 2-f, 3-e, 4-b, 5-d, 6-a:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-e, 2-g, 3-b, 4-d, 5-a, 6-c

Option B - 1-c, 2-f, 3-b, 4-a, 5-e, 6-g

Option C - 1-e, 2-g, 3-a, 4-b, 5-d, 6-c

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother complaining of anxiety, shyness and failure to speak in social situations, while being able to speak normally in other situations. Which of the following is the condition that is mentioned here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  C - Selective mutism:

  • It is a failure of a child to speak in specific social situations, while being able to speak normally in other situations
  • For eg: Child speaking normally at home with everyone but at school he does not speak at all
  • It is a manifestation of underlying anxiety disorder or excessive shyness or dependency on parents
  • There can be a history of anxiety symptoms in one or both parents
  • Treatment: Behavioral therapy to reduce underlying anxiety

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ADHD:

  • Persistent hyperactivity/inattention or impulsivity that interferes with day to day functioning/development of child
  • Onset: Before 12 years of age that has been present for at least 6 months in at least 2 different settings (school/home/play area) without any underlying secondary known cause

Option B - Autism spectrum disorder:

  • It is defined as persistent impairment in reciprocal social interaction and presence of restricted, repetitive pattern of behavior or interest
  • Child will not smile or hold an eye contact with other people
  • Some children will be very intellectual or bright while some of others will have intellectual disability

Option D - Rett syndrome:

  • Most common gene mutation: MECP 2 gene mutation
  • Head circumference is normal at birth but later these children develop acquired microcephaly
  • Loss of purposeful hand movement & Appearance of stereotypic hand wringing movement

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.solution:
Correct |Option C - Degeneracy:

  • One of the characteristics of the genetic code is that it is degenerate, meaning that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid.
  • The Wobble hypothesis suggests that while the first two positions of a codon and anticodon must form specific base pairs (A-U and G-C), the third position allows for flexibility or "wobble" in base pairing.
  • This flexibility explains how multiple codons can code for the same amino acid, contributing to the degeneracy of the genetic code.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Universal: Genetic code is considered universal because humans, animals, plants and bacteria all have the exact same genetic code.

Option B - Unambiguous: The genetic code is unambiguous since a codon always codes for a specific amino acid. It does not code for another amino acid.

Option D - Non-punctuate: No internal punctuation is used in the code. Thus, the code is said to be commaless. Thus once the translation of mRNA begins, the code is read in a non-contiguous fashion i.e one after the other with no breaks between them

questions.text: Determine the respiratory quotient (RQ) of a patient weighing 50 kg who exhales 200 ml/min of CO2 and consumed 250 ml/min O2.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 0.8:

  • To calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ), we need to determine the ratio of carbon dioxide production (VCO2) to oxygen consumption (VO2). The formula for RQ is:
    • RQ = VCO2 / VO2
    • Given the values: CO2 exhaled (VCO2) = 200 ml/min O2 consumed (VO2) = 250 ml/min
    • Substituting these values into the formula:
      • RQ = 200 ml/min / 250 ml/min RQ = 0.8

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: During the class on breastfeeding by a renowned pediatrician, several mothers were given descriptions of good signs of attachment during breastfeeding and correct breastfeeding positioning. The pediatrician asked several questions of which one question was about the type of milk that satisfies the baby's hunger. Which of the following milk satisfies the hunger of the baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hind milk:

  • It satisfies the hunger of the baby.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fore milk

Option B - Mature milk

Option D - Transitional milk

  • These milk do not satisfy the hunger of the baby.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and heart failure presents to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances. On examination, his pulse is irregularly irregular, blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and he appears disoriented. An ECG is performed, revealing a normal sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 60 beats per minute, increased PR interval, and inverted T waves. Given his symptoms and ECG findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Digoxin toxicity:

  • Given the patient's history of atrial fibrillation and heart failure, along with the presenting symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and visual disturbances, and the ECG findings of normal sinus rhythm with increased PR interval and inverted T waves, the most likely diagnosis is digoxin toxicity.
  • Digoxin is commonly used in the management of atrial fibrillation and heart failure due to its ability to improve contractility and control heart rate. However, it has a narrow therapeutic index, and toxicity can occur, especially in elderly patients or those with impaired renal function.
  • Typical symptoms of digoxin toxicity include gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea and vomiting, as well as visual disturbances (such as yellow halos around lights) and neurological symptoms (such as confusion or disorientation).
  • The ECG findings of increased PR interval and inverted T waves are consistent with digoxin toxicity.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Acute Myocardial Infarction:

  • Symptoms and ECG findings are not typical of acute myocardial infarction.

Option C - Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response:

  • ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, not atrial fibrillation.

Option D - Hyperkalemia:

  • Symptoms and ECG findings do not match typical presentation of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is present in the third layer of plantar muscles?
questions.solution:
Option A: Adductor hallucis

  • 3rd layer: Adductor hallucis, flexor hallucis brevis, Flexor digiti minimi brevis
  • The adductor hallucis muscle is innervated by lateral plantar nerve (S-2, 3) nad it adducts the big toe.
  • Flexor hallucis brevis is innervated by medial plantar nerve (S-2, 3) and it flexes proximal phalanx of the big toe.
  • Flexor digiti minimi brevis is innervated by lateral plantar nerve (S-2, 3) and flexes proximal phalanx of the little toe. 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B: Abductor hallucis

  • The abductor hallucis muscle is located on the medial border of the foot and contributes to forming the prominence that is observed in the region.
  • It is inserted behind the tuberosity of the calcaneus, the flexor retinaculum, and the plantar aponeurosis.
  • Abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, and abductor digiti minimi are part of the first layer of the plantar muscle.

Option C: Lumbricals

  • Lumbricals, along with quadratus plantae, form the second layer of the plantar muscles
  • The lumbricals arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum longus muscle, as far back as their angles of division, each springing from two tendons, except the first.
  • The first lumbrical is unipennate, while the second, third and fourth are bipennate.
  • All four lumbricals insert into extensor hoods of the phalanges, thus creating extension at the inter-phalangeal (PIP and DIP) joints.
  • However, as the tendons also pass inferior to the metatarsal phalangeal (MTP) joints, it creates flexion at this joint.

Option D: Interossei

  • Plantar and dorsal interossei from the deepest layer of plantar muscles.
  • The four interossei muscles are bipenniform muscles, each originating from two heads from the proximal half of the sides of adjacent metatarsal bones.
  • They mainly abduct toes.

questions.text:
Match the readings of various serum markers with their respective diagnosis:


	
		
			
			1. HBs Ag⊕ + IgM anti-HBc
			
			
			a. Gap period
			
		
		
			
			2. Hbs Ag⊕ + IgG anti-HBc
			
			
			b. Vaccinated
			
		
		
			
			3. Only IgM anti-HBcAg is present
			
			
			c. Acute Hepatitis B
			
		
		
			
			4. Anti HbsAg > 10 IU/ml
			
			
			d. Recovery
			
		
		
			
			5. IgG Anti Hbc
			
			
			e. Chronic Hepatitis B
			
		
		
			
			6. Anti Hbs Ag(+), Anti Hbc Ig G(+)
			
			
			f. Low-level carrier
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-c,2-e,3-a,4-b,5-f,6-d:

1. HBs Ag⊕ + IgM anti-HBc c. Acute Hepatitis B
2. Hbs Ag⊕ + IgG anti-HBc e. Chronic Hepatitis B
3. Only IgM anti-HBcAg is present a. Gap period
4. Anti HbsAg > 10 IU/ml b. Vaccinated
5. IgG Anti Hbc f. Low-level carrier
6. Anti Hbs Ag(+), Anti HbcIg G. (+) d. Recovery

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about the marked structure?

choices.text: It is the largest air cell
It extends into the sphenoid sinus
It is present inferomedial in the floor of the orbit
It is the first ethmoidal air cell

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - It is the first ethmoidal air cell:

The marked structure is the Agger Nassi cells.

 

Agger Nasi

The Agger Nasi is the anterior most or the 1st ethmoid air cell.

Bulla ethmoidalis
  • Bulla Ethmoidalis is behind the Aggar Nasi.
  • It is the Largest ethmoidal air cell

Onodi cell
  • The Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal air cell that extends into the sphenoid sinus in the posterior and lateral directions
  • Sometimes, it contains optic nerve within it.
  • Sometimes, it may also contain internal carotid artery

Haller cell
  • An ethmoidal air cell which is present inferomedial in the floor of the orbit known as Haller cell.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is the largest air cell: Bulla ethmoidalis is the largest air cell, not Agger Nassi cells.

Option B - It extends into the sphenoid sinus: Onodi cells extend into the sphenoid sinus, not Agger Nassi cells.

Option C - It is present inferomedial to the floor of the orbit: Haller cells are present inferomedial in the floor of the orbit, not Agger Nassi cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida was brought to the clinic by her spouse for an antenatal checkup. On examination, her vitals were stable. The doctor advised a USG and the report showed a twin pregnancy that involved the formation of two fetuses from the splitting of one embryo. Which of the following is the most common type of the twin pregnancy mentioned in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Monochorionic diamniotic:

  • Monochorionic diamniotic is the most common type of monozygotic twins.
  • The most common type of twin pregnancy that involves the formation of two fetuses from the splitting of one embryo is known as monozygotic twins.
  • Monochorionic diamniotic (MCDA) twins are actually the most common type of monozygotic twins, accounting for approximately two-thirds of all monozygotic twin pregnancies. In MCDA twins, the zygote splits into two embryos relatively early in development, usually within the first few days after fertilization.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • Dichorionic diamniotic, Monochorionic monoamniotic, and Conjoint twins are the types of Monozygotic twins but not the most common variant.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a known history of rheumatoid arthritis presented to the OPD with complaints of a burning and gritty sensation. O/E the ophthalmologist observes mucus filaments as shown in the image, which ocular condition is most likely affecting this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca also called Dry eye syndrome is caused due to deficiency in the aqueous layer of tear film. The patient gives a history of rheumatoid arthritis along with the clinical feature of burning, gritty sensation, and mucus filaments observed during examination suggests the diagnosis as keratoconjunctivitis, which is the most common ocular feature seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Mucus filaments are seen due to excessive mucus deposition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allergic conjunctivitis: Allergic conjunctivitis is characterized by redness, itching, and watery discharge caused due to exogenous allergens or endogenous antigens, seen in patients suffering from asthma or eczema. Mucus filaments are not a typical finding in allergic conjunctivitis.

Option C - Acute angle-closure glaucoma: Acute angle-closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden-onset severe eye pain, blurred vision, and headache due to high IOP. Mucus filaments are not associated with angle-closure glaucoma.

Option D – Corneal abrasion: Corneal abrasion involves a scratch or injury to the cornea, leading to symptoms such as pain, tearing, and sensitivity to light. Mucus filaments are not a characteristic finding in corneal abrasion.

questions.text:
A public health officer is investigating an outbreak of viral infections in a rural community. Several individuals have presented with symptoms, including fever, headache, and fatigue. Upon further investigation, it is discovered that different viruses are responsible for the illnesses. The officer asked her students to identify and match the viruses with their respective families to manage and control the outbreak effectively.

Match the following viruses with their families:


	
		
			
			Virus
			
			
			Family
			
		
		
			
			1. Ebola virus
			
			
			a. Single-stranded RNA Flavivirus
			
		
		
			
			2. Zika virus
			
			
			b. Filoviridae family
			
		
		
			
			3. Nipah virus
			
			
			c. Paramyxoviridae family
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-b, 2-a, 3-c:

  • Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae. This family includes filamentous viruses with single-stranded, negative-sense RNA genomes. Ebola virus is notorious for causing severe hemorrhagic fever outbreaks in humans.
  • Nipah virus belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae. Paramyxoviridae encompasses enveloped viruses with single-stranded, negative-sense RNA genomes. Nipah virus is known for causing severe respiratory and neurological symptoms, often leading to fatal encephalitis.
  • Zika virus belongs to the family Flaviviridae. Flaviviridae consists of enveloped viruses with single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genomes. Zika virus gained international attention due to its association with microcephaly and other congenital abnormalities during outbreaks in various regions.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These do not indicate the correct match between the virus and the family.

questions.text: Emma, a 9-year-old student, has difficulty recognizing words, exhibits slow and inaccurate reading, experiences poor comprehension, and struggles with spelling. Which specific learning disorder is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dyslexia:

  • Dyslexia is a specific learning disorder characterized by difficulty in recognizing words, slow and inaccurate reading, poor comprehension, and spelling difficulties. This aligns with Emma's symptoms and is the correct answer.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dysgraphia: Dysgraphia is a specific learning disorder characterized by difficulties in handwriting and written expression. It does not involve reading difficulties.

Option B - Dyscalculia: Dyscalculia is a specific learning disorder related to mathematical abilities, such as difficulty with number recognition, counting, and solving mathematical problems. It is not associated with reading impairments.

Option D - Dyspraxia: Dyspraxia, also known as developmental coordination disorder, involves difficulties with coordination, motor skills, and physical movements. It does not directly affect reading abilities.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician complaining of itching, redness, and watery discharge from both eyes. A sample streaked with Staphylococcus aureus and left overnight shows the following findings. What is the probable organism responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Haemophilus:

  • Haemophilus spp. requires either or both of the X-factor (hemin or protoporphyrin IX) and V-factor (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD)) for their growth and survival. Haemophilus spp. can be distinguished down to the level of the species based on whether they require either one or both of these growth factors.
  • The finding shown in the image is known as Satellitism.
  • The patient is suspected of having conjunctivitis due to Haemophilus influenza.

Satellitism

  • The growth of Haemophilus influenzae is scanty on blood agar, as factor V is not freely available, being imprisoned inside the red blood cells. Growth is, therefore, better if the source of the V factor is also provided.
  • When Staph aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which a specimen containing H. influenzae has been inoculated, after overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well developed alongside the streak of staphylococcus and smaller further away. This phenomenon is called satellitism.
  • Satellitism is due to the release of a high concentration of factor 'V' present in red blood cells by staphylococcus aureus, which is released into the medium and is used by H. influenzae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Streptococcus:

  • Very occasionally, Satellitism is done by streptococcus species, Neisseria, and Diphtheroid.
  • Streptococcus rarely can show satellitism but is unlikely to cause conjunctivitis. 

Option C- Klebsiella:

  • Satellitism is not done by Klebsiella.
  • Klebsiella grows on blood agar, but its colonies are non-hemolytic.

Option D- Proteus:

  • Proteus grows in a successive waveform pattern on the blood agar plate to make concentric circles. This is called a swarming pattern. A bacteria showing a swarming pattern does not form discrete colonies on blood agar.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of vitreous hemorrhage presents with elevated intraocular pressure and visual disturbances. Ocular examination reveals the presence of small, refractile, brownish cells in the anterior chamber. What is the most likely cause of the elevated intraocular pressure in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Ghost Cell Glaucoma:

  • Ghost cell glaucoma occurs when red blood cells released during a vitreous hemorrhage convert into ghost cells by loosing their iron and hemoglobin . These cells can obstruct the trabecular meshwork, leading to elevated intraocular pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Open-angle glaucoma:

  • Open-angle glaucoma typically involves a gradual increase in intraocular pressure without the presence of distinct cells in the anterior chamber, as described in the scenario.

Option B - Neovascular glaucoma:

  • Neovascular glaucoma is associated with the growth of abnormal blood vessels, often seen in conditions like diabetic retinopathy. The scenario, however, describes the presence of brownish cells rather than neovascularization. 

Option C - Angle-closure glaucoma:

  • Angle-closure glaucoma is characterized by the closure of the angle between the iris and the cornea, leading to increased intraocular pressure.

questions.text: In a physiology seminar, a professor explains different types of membrane receptors. He explains that membrane proteins are divided into integral proteins and peripheral proteins. GPCR (G Protein Coupled Receptor) is an example of an integral protein present in the cell membrane. Which among the following statements is true of integral proteins?

choices.text: Are not attached to the outer leaflet
Are not attached to the inner leaflet
Van der Waals forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer
Electrostatic forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer

questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Van der Waals forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer:

  • Integral proteins, including GPCRs, are embedded within the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. The attachment is facilitated by hydrophobic interactions and van der Waals forces, between the hydrophobic regions of the integral proteins and the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Are not attached to the outer leaflet: This statement is incorrect. Integral proteins are indeed attached to the lipid bilayer, and they span the membrane from the outer to the inner leaflet.

Option B – Are not attached to the inner leaflet: This statement is incorrect. Integral proteins span the entire lipid bilayer, being embedded in both the outer and inner leaflets.

Option D – Electrostatic forces are responsible for attachment with the lipid bilayer: This statement is incorrect. Electrostatic forces are responsible for the attachment of peripheral proteins with the integral proteins.

questions.text: A 25 year old male comes to the OPD with complaints of nausea and vomiting while travelling. He claims that it happens only while traveling. This condition can be treated with antimuscarinic and antihistaminic drugs. Identify the antimuscarinic drug.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyoscine:

  • This is a case of Motion sickness.
  • Hyoscine is antimuscarinic drug used in the treatment of Motion sickness.
  • It can be given as oral form and as transdermal patch.
    • Transdermal patch attached behind pinna (posterior auricular area)
  • Drug must be taken at least 30 minutes before journey.
    • Only for prevention of motion sickness
    • Not effective if vomiting has started
    • Block vestibular nerve before it trigger CTZ
    • If vomiting already started, let the patient vomit and then give drugs that can prevent another episode.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A,B,D: Meclizine, Cyclizine, Promethazine

  • These are antihistaminic drugs given in the treatment of Motion sickness.
  • Other drugs used are
    • Diphenhydramine (available as transdermal patch)
    • Cinnarizine.
  • Side effects
    • Sedation
    • Ephedrine is added to prevent sedation - but ephedrine do not prevent nausea and vomiting in motion sickness.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			
			
			
			A
			
			
			Perkin’s Mastoid Retractor
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			
			
			
			B
			
			
			Wietlaner’s Mastoid Retractor
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			
			
			
			C
			
			
			Jansen’s Mastoid Retractor
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			
			
			
			D
			
			
			Mollison Mastoid Retractor
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C:

1

D

Mollison Mastoid Retractor

  • It is a self-retaining retractor that helps to achieve hemostasis by compressing the tissue.
  • It is used in mastoid surgery.
  • It is a hands-free instrument since it is self-retaining.
  • Presence of an equal number of prongs in the arm of the retractor.

2

A

Perkin’s Mastoid Retractor

  • This retractor has a single prong on one side and three prongs on the other side.

3

B

  • It has an unequal number of prongs in the arm of retractor.

 

4

C

questions.text: A 49-year-old female was scheduled for herniorrhaphy. During the surgery, the surgeon observed that the shape of the hernia was in a “W” shape, as shown in the image below. What is the name of the hernia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Maydl's hernia :

  • The picture shown above is that of a Maydl hernia.
  • The hernial sac has two loops of the bowel, one of which is intra-abdominal. The hernial sac contains a loop of the bowel in the shape of a 'W', and the center section of the 'W' loop may become strangulated, either alone or in conjunction with the bowel in the hernial sac.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Richter’s hernia:

  • A Richter's hernia arises when the intestine's antimesenteric wall protrudes through a hole in the abdominal wall.

Option B - Littre's hernia:

  • The protrusion of a Meckel diverticulum through a possible abdominal orifice is referred to as a Littre hernia.

Option C - Pantaloon hernia:

  • A pantaloon hernia, also known as a "Saddlebag" hernia, is defined as any combination of two contiguous femoral or inguinal hernia sacs on the same side .

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with recurrent and severe nosebleeds necessitating blood transfusions is being considered for surgical intervention. What is the most appropriate surgical procedure in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Young's operation:

  • In severe cases of HHT requiring blood transfusion, the recommended surgical procedure is Young's operation.
  • Young's operation involves the complete closure of the nasal cavity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Septodermoplasty: In septodermoplasty the mucosa is elevated over the septum and the entire mucosa is removed. It is preferred in moderate cases of HHT which does not require blood transfusion.

Option B - Laser photocoagulation: Laser photocoagulation is used for mild bleeding in HHT, but it is not used for severe cases requiring blood transfusion.

Option D - Caldwell Luc operation: Caldwell Luc operation is not a part of the management of HHT.

questions.text: What medical device, depicted below, is most likely recommended for a 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension and myocardial ischemia who is admitted to the cardiology ward due to rhythm issues?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Automated External Defibrillator:

  • The above image is of Automated External Defibrillator.
  • Automated External Defibrillator:
    • It is an advanced, microprocessor-based portable device.
    • High specificity and sensitivity in differentiating shockable from non-shockable rhythms. 
    • Delivers an electric shock through the chest to the heart, potentially stopping arrhythmias.
    • Compared with monophasic shocks, biphasic shocks deliver energy in two directions with equivalent efficacy at lower energy levels and possibly with less myocardial injury.
    • When using AEDs, one electrode pad is placed beside the upper right sternal border, just below the clavicle, and the other pad is placed just lateral to the left nipple, with the top of the pad a few inches below the axilla.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulse oximeter:

  • It is used to monitor the oxygen saturation.

Option B - Sphygmomanometer:

  • It is used to measure blood pressure.

Option C - Manual external defibrillator:

  • The manual device for defibrillation does not automatically identify and treat the abnormal rhythm.
  • However, the success rates are comparable to the automatic defibrillator

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is diagnosed with a deficiency in a specific receptor responsible for the uptake of globulin proteins. As a result, there is impaired cellular internalization of these macromolecules, affecting their transport within the cell. Which cellular process is primarily affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Clathrin-mediated endocytosis:

  • In this scenario, where a specific receptor responsible for the uptake of globulin proteins is deficient and cellular internalization is impaired, clathrin-mediated endocytosis is primarily affected.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Phagocytosis: Phagocytosis is the process of engulfing large particles or microorganisms and is not associated with the uptake of specific proteins like globulin.

Option B – Pinocytosis: Pinocytosis is the nonspecific uptake of small droplets of extracellular fluid and does not involve the specific uptake of globulin proteins.

Option D – Exocytosis: Exocytosis is the process of releasing substances from intracellular vesicles into the extracellular space and is not related to the impaired uptake of globulin proteins.

questions.text: A mother brought her 10-year-old child to the clinic with concerns about the appearance of blue discoloration of the eyes. On examination, the following finding is seen in the image. Which of the following conditions is not commonly associated with the condition this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Angelman syndrome:

  • Blue sclera refers to the bluish appearance of the normally white sclera due to the thinning of the sclera (the outer layer of the eye). The bluish appearance is due to the underlying uveal tissue. It is typically associated with certain genetic or connective tissue disorders but it is not associated with Angelman syndrome. Angelman syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder caused by a genetic abnormality on chromosome 15. It is more commonly associated with other physical and behavioral manifestations, such as developmental delays, intellectual disability, seizures, and a happy demeanour.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteogenesis imperfecta: This is the correct association. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones and connective tissue abnormalities. The blue sclera is a well-known feature of this condition. The underlying collagen defects in osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to the translucent appearance of the sclera. 

Option B - Ehlers-Danlos syndrome: This is the correct association. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is a group of genetic disorders that affect the connective tissues of the body, including the sclera. Blue sclera is a common feature in some subtypes of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. The abnormal collagen synthesis can cause the sclera to appear thin.

Option C - Marfan syndrome: This is the correct association. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular systems. While the main ocular feature of Marfan syndrome is lens dislocation, blue sclera can also be observed in some individuals with this condition. The structural abnormalities in the connective tissue, including the sclera, contribute to scleral thinning.

questions.text: Using the chest Xray below, identify the congenital heart disorder.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Transposition of great vessels:

  • The x-ray shows a heart which is egg-shaped.
  • The egg on the side is the characteristic X-ray finding of the transposition of great vessels

Incorrect Options:

Option B - TAPVC: Chest X-ray in TAPVC shows Snowman or Figure of 8 appearance

Option D - Coarctation of the aorta: Chest X-ray shows Figure of 3 appearance

Option A - Truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus eliminated by the explanation of the above options

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and palpitations. She has a past medical history of rheumatic fever. On physical examination, an opening snap was followed by a low-pitched diastolic rumble,which is best heard at the apex. The patient undergoes an echocardiogram, which reveals thickening and immobility of the mitral valve leaflets. Additionally,  a chest X-ray is done.

 

Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical presentation and radiographic findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Options B - Mitral stenosis:

  •  Mitral stenosis refers to the narrowing of the mitral valve, leading to impaired blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. It is commonly caused by rheumatic fever. The clinical presentation of exertional dyspnea, fatigue, palpitations, and the characteristic physical examination findings of an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic rumble at the apex are suggestive of mitral stenosis. The X-ray findings of left atrial enlargement, "third mogul sign" (prominent left atrial appendage), and "walking man sign"straightening of left heart border are consistent with the diagnosis of mitral stenosis.

Walking Man Sign

Third Mogul Sign

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aortic stenosis: Aortic stenosis refers to the narrowing of the aortic valve, leading to obstruction of blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. It typically presents with a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right upper sternal border.

Option C - Aortic regurgitation: It typically presents with a high-pitched blowing diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border.

Option D - Mitral regurgitation:  It presents with a holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex, often radiating to the axilla.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. Blood pressure on admission is 190/110 mmHg. After initial stabilization, a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is suspected. Which of the following medications is considered the best option for preoperative hypertension management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phenoxybenzamine:

  • Phenoxybenzamine: This is a non-selective alpha-blocker and is considered the best drug for the preoperative management of hypertension in patients with pheochromocytoma.
  • It irreversibly blocks alpha-adrenergic receptors, preventing vasoconstriction caused by catecholamines released by the tumor. It is used to control blood pressure and reduce the risk of hypertensive crisis during surgery.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A - Propranolol: While a beta-blocker, propranolol is contraindicated in pheochromocytoma until alpha blockade is achieved. If given without alpha blockade, unopposed alpha stimulation can worsen hypertension and lead to a hypertensive crisis.
  • Option B - Hydralazine: This is a direct-acting vasodilator and is not the first-line choice for preoperative management of pheochromocytoma. Alpha blockade is preferred.
  • Option D - Amlodipine: This is a calcium channel blocker, not typically used in the immediate management of pheochromocytoma-related hypertension. Alpha blockade is the primary approach.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep. The symptoms have been present for the past 4 days and are not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Hypomania

  • The patient's presentation of an elevated mood, increased energy, and decreased need for sleep lasting for more than 4 days suggests hypomania. Hypomania is a milder form of mania and is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning.

  • Criteria

    Mania

    Hypomania

    Duration

    At least one week

    At least four consecutive days

    Severity

    Severe impairment in functioning and may need hospitalization

    Less severe than mania, no psychotic features

    Impairment

    Often requires hospitalization or is disruptive to daily life

    Typically less severe and less disruptive to daily life

    Symptoms

    Exaggerated elevation in mood

    Elevated mood, increased activity

    Energy

    Highly energetic, excessive

    Increased but manageable

    Risky Behavior

    Pronounced and risky behavior

    Risk-taking behavior, but less extreme

    Psychotic Features

    Often present (hallucinations, delusions)

    Absent

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Major depressive disorder: The patient does not exhibit symptoms of a major depressive episode. Major depressive disorder is characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and loss of interest or pleasure in activities. The scenario describes an elevated mood, which is inconsistent with a major depressive episode.

Option C - Generalized anxiety disorder: The patient's symptoms are not indicative of generalized anxiety disorder. Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive worry and anxiety about various events or activities, whereas the scenario describes an elevated mood and increased energy.

Option D - Borderline personality disorder: The patient's symptoms are more indicative of a mood disorder (hypomania) rather than a personality disorder. Borderline personality disorder is characterized by unstable moods, impulsivity, and difficulties with interpersonal relationships.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures is NOT considered part of Basic emergency Obs care services?

choices.text: Assisted vaginal delivery in Community Health Centers (CHCs)

questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Blood transfusion:

  • Basic emergency obstetric care includes essential interventions that can be provided at the first referral level of healthcare facilities, typically at health centers.
  • These interventions are crucial for managing obstetric emergencies and reducing maternal mortality.
  • Blood transfusion is a part of comprehensive emergency obstetric care.

 

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with upper abdominal pain. She had been previously diagnosed and treated for recurrent purulent vaginal discharge. Diagnostic laparoscopy revealed the following image. Which of the following statements is inappropriate regarding this patient?

choices.text: It may lpresent with right upper quadrant pain
The pain may refer to the shoulder or upper arm
It is most commonly associated with tubercular salpingitis

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Most commonly associated with tubercular salpingitis

  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is most commonly associated with pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by sexually transmitted infections such as Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, rather than tubercular salpingitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: May lead to right upper quadrant pain

  • The pain in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is localized in the right upper quadrant because the liver is involved due to the formation of violin string-like fibrous bands.
  • That is why it is also called perihepatitis.

Option B: Pain may refer to the shoulder or upper arm

  • The upper abdominal pain caused by perihepatitis (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome) may refer to the shoulder or upper arm.

Option D: Pain resembles cholecystitis

  • The pain in Fitz-Hugh-Curtis is localized in the right upper quadrant resembling the pain of cholecystitis.
  • That is why cholecystitis is also a differential for Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the other use of Premenstrual endometrial biopsy other than detecting ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - To detect TB:

  • The other use of Premenstrual endometrial biopsy is to detect TB
  • It is performed around days 20 to 24 under general or local anesthesia
  • Intercourse should be avoided the whole month in which the premenstrual endometrial biopsy is scheduled to avoid the risk of accidental abortion
  • It is done to check secretory changes: If the secretory changes are present then we know that ovulation occurred.
    • Check adequate secretory changes: For every day of the month endometrial changes are different
    • Luteal phase defect (reason for infertility): When the difference between expected and observed changes is ≥ 2 days

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are not the other uses of Premenstrual endometrial biopsy

questions.text: A scientist is trying to create a restriction map of various mutant and wild-type genes involved in a novel cancerous cell line of the liver. In one of his experiments, DNA extracted from the cells is first treated with restriction enzymes and then pipetted into the wells of agarose gel, and the gel is subjected  to an electric field. In the last step of his experiment, the gel is stained with ethidium bromide and visualized under ultraviolet light. Which of the following is the best term for the described procedure
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - DNA Gel electrophoresis:

DNA gel electrophoresis is the best term for the described procedure.

  • DNA fragments are separated based on size by applying an electric field to an agarose gel.
  • Negatively charged DNA molecules move towards the positive end of the gel.
  • Smaller fragments move faster, resulting in separation into bands.
  • Ethidium bromide staining and visualization under UV light reveal the separated DNA bands.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Southern blot:

  • Identifies specific DNA sequences by hybridization with labeled DNA probes after transfer to a filter.

Option B - Polymerase chain reaction (PCR):

  • Amplifies specific DNA sequences, producing millions of copies in a short time.

Option C - Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA):

  • Detects the presence of antigens or antibodies through color formation or precipitation in a sample

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivered a baby boy weighing 2.2 kg. On examination, the baby appeared to be stable and active. The pediatrician advised skin-to-skin contact of the neonate with the mother as an efficacious alternative to warmer care. What is the recommended duration for this care process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Minimum 1 hour per session: 

  • Kangaroo mother care refers to the care of preterm or low birth weight infants by placing the infant in skin-to-skin contact with the mother or any other caregiver.
  • Initially perceived as an alternative to warmer care for LBW infants, KMC has now become the standard of care for these babies.
  • Is as good as incubator care regarding safety and thermal protection.
  • A minimum of 1 hour per session of KMC should be done.
  • Sessions that last less than an hour should be avoided because frequent handling may stress the baby.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D - Minimum 2 hours per session / Minimum 3 hours per session & Minimum 4 hours per session: These are not correct.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency room after he sustained a road traffic accident. His blood pressure is 88/76 mm Hg, and his pulse rate is 126 per minute. On examination, he appears pale and somnolent. Which of the following correctly represents the formula of the Modified Shock Index (MSI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Heart rate / Mean arterial pressure

  • Modified shock index is heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • High MSI indicates a value of stroke volume and low systemic vascular resistance, a sign of hypodynamic circulation.
  • Low MSI indicates hyperdynamic circulation.
  • MSI is a better marker than stroke index for mortality rate prediction

Option A: Heart rate / systolic BP

  • The heart rate divided by systolic BP is called the shock index.
  • It is a better marker for assessing the severity of shock than heart rate & blood pressure alone.

Option B: Heart rate / diastolic BP

  • Modified Stroke Index is heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Pulse rate / Systolic BP

  • Modified Stroke Index is heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Below are images showing various clinical tests. Identify them and mark the correct option having the names of the tests for assessing ACL injury.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2, 3:

  • 1 - Lachman test

    • Lachman Test

      • Patient in the supine position.
      • Knee flexed to 30°
      • The examiner places one hand behind the tibia with the thumb on the tibial tuberosity.
      • More than 2mm of anterior translation associated with a 'soft end feel' is considered positive.
      • Lachman test - More reliable, More sensitive than Anterior Drawers Test. 

    • Superior to Anterior Drawers Test

      • Less hurtful to the patient.
      • No doorstep phenomenon.
      • Gold standard physical test.
  • 2 - Anterior drawer test

    • Anterior Drawer Test

      • Patient in the supine position.
      • Hip flexed to 45°, Knee flexed to 90°
      • Examiner sits on the patient's feet.
      • Thumb of both hands on the tibial tuberosity.
      • This test is considered positive if there is a 'soft end feel.'
      • Less accurate than Lachman Test
      • Associated medial meniscus injury.
      • The doorstep phenomenon is present in ACL injury associated with the posterior horn of medial meniscal tear injury.
  • 3 - Pivot shift test

    • Pivot Shift Test-

      • Pivot Shift Test is a special test used to diagnose the rotatory instability related to injury of the ACL of the knee.
      • The patient is supine.
      • The examiner grasps and immobilizes the lateral femoral condyle with one hand and palpates the proximal tibia or fibula with the thumb.
      • Conversely, the examiner holds the patient's lower leg in internal rotation and abduction (valgus stress).
      • From this starting position, the knee is then moved from extension into flexion.
      • In the presence of a torn anterior cruciate ligament, the valgus stress will cause the tibia to subluxate anteriorly while the knee is still in extension.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

  • 4 - Godfrey sign in posterior drawer test is done is PCL injury

    • Godfrey sign

      • This is otherwise called the Gravity Sign or Sag Sign.
      • When viewed from the side, there is an abnormal posterior translation of the Tibia, accentuated by the hamstrings' contraction.
  • 5 - Apley’s grinding test done in meniscus injury

    • Apley's Grinding Test

      • Step I - Patient in a prone position with knee flexed to 90°.
      • Step II - The patient's thigh is fixed to the examination table with the examiner's knee.
      • Step III - The examiner medially & laterally rotates the Tibia combined with distraction. If there is
      • pain associated with excessive rotations; it is a ligamentous injury.
      • Step IV - The examiner medially & laterally rotates the Tibia combined with compression. If there is
      • pain associated with the restriction of rotations; it is a meniscal injury.
      • Apley's Grinding Test has 87% specificity & 97% sensitivity.
  • 6 - Mcmurray’s test in meniscus injury

    • McMurray Test

      • Step-I: The patient is in the supine position. The examiner holds the knee and palpates the joint line. The other hand holds the sole.
      • Step II: He is kept in full flexion.
      • Step III: The examiner applies valgus stress to the knee. With the other hand, the foot & leg are externally rotated.
      • Step IV: The knee is gradually extended.
      • Step-V: Audible click & pain denotes medial meniscal tear.

questions.text: If iodine in the diet was completely stopped today, approximately how many days would it take for the levels of thyroid hormones in the bloodstream to reach zero?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 90 days:

  • It would take approximately 90 days for the levels of thyroid hormones in the bloodstream to reach zero if iodine intake were completely stopped today. This is because the thyroid gland has enough stores of thyroxine and triiodothyronine to sustain normal levels for 2-3 months, even without iodine supplementation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D: do not accurately represent the time it takes for thyroid hormone levels to reach zero after iodine intake is stopped. The correct duration is approximately 90 days, as explained above.

questions.text: Which combination in the diagram below incorrectly illustrates the developmental origin of the urogenital system?
questions.solution:
Option B: 3-Mesonephric duct

  • The urinary bladder is labelled as ‘3’ in the above diagram.
  • The mesonephric duct is responsible for forming the genital tracts of the male reproductive system and the trigone of the bladder. In contrast, the bladder is developed from the urogenital sinus during the embryonic period.

Option Aand C: 2-Paramesonephric duct

  • The Mullerian duct is also known as the paramesonephric duct and is involved in the embryological development of the uterine tube (label 1) and the uterus cavity(label 2).

Option D: 4-Urogenital sinus

  • There are three portions of the urogenital sinus.
    • The upper and largest part is the urinary bladder.
