questions.text: Which among the following joints is/are related to Chopart's ligament?
questions.solution:
Option D: Calcaneocuboid joint and Calcaneonavicular joint

  • The bifurcate ligament (Chopart's ligament) is a strong Y-shaped band.
  • It is attached by its stem proximally to the anterior part of the upper calcaneal surface, and distally it divides into calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular parts.
  • A separate ligament, the lateral calcaneocuboid ligaments, extends to the dorsomedial aspect of the cuboid, forming the main bond between the two rows of tarsal bones; the (medial) calcaneonavicular ligament is attached to the dorsolateral aspect of the navicular.

Option A: Calcaneocuboid joint

  • The calcaneocuboid joint is related to the chopart ligament; however, the calcaneonavicular joint is also related to the chopart ligament.

Option B: Naviculocuneiform joint

  • The naviculocuneiform joint is not related to the chopart ligament.

Option C: Calcaneonavicular joint

  • The calcaneonavicular joint is related to the chopart ligament; however, the calcaneocuboid joint is also related to the chopart ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following ocular manifestations is most consistent with Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome (VKS) based on the provided fundus photograph?

choices.text: Retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots
Optic disc edema with macular star exudates
Dilated and tortuous retinal vessels with flame-shaped hemorrhages
Multifocal serous retinal detachments with choroidal thickening

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Multifocal serous retinal detachments with choroidal thickening:

  • The provided fundus photograph shows bilateral multifocal serous retinal detachments, which are characterized by the accumulation of fluid between the neurosensory retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. This is a hallmark finding in Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome (VKS). Additionally, the photograph also reveals choroidal thickening, which is another significant feature of VKS. Choroid is the vascular layer beneath the retina, and its thickening can lead to various ocular manifestations in VKS. Other common ocular manifestations in VKS include uveitis (inflammation of the uveal tract), exudative retinal detachments, and disc hyperemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots:

  • This option is more consistent with hypertensive retinopathy or diabetic retinopathy, where retinal blood vessel abnormalities can lead to retinal hemorrhages and cotton wool spots. It is not a typical feature of Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome.

Option B - Optic disc edema with macular star exudates:

  • This finding is more characteristic of papilledema, often caused by increased intracranial pressure. It is not a typical feature of Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome.

Option C - Dilated and tortuous retinal vessels with flame-shaped hemorrhages:

  • These findings are associated with hypertensive retinopathy, where chronic hypertension can lead to damage in retinal blood vessels, causing dilatation, tortuosity, and flame-shaped hemorrhages. It is not specific to Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the difference between typical and atypical antipsychotics in the treatment of schizophrenia?

choices.text: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.
Atypical antipsychotics are associated with a higher risk of extrapyramidal symptoms compared to typical antipsychotics.
Typical antipsychotics are more likely to cause metabolic side effects such as weight gain, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia than atypical antipsychotics.
Atypical antipsychotics primarily antagonize D2 receptors, while typical antipsychotics antagonize both D2 and 5HT2A receptors.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Typical antipsychotics primarily act on positive symptoms, while atypical antipsychotics target both positive and negative symptoms.

 

  • Typical Antipsychotics (First Generation): These medications primarily act on positive symptoms of schizophrenia, which include hallucinations, delusions, and thought disorders. They achieve this effect by antagonizing dopamine D2 receptors in the brain, reducing the excessive dopamine activity associated with positive symptoms.
  • Atypical Antipsychotics (Second Generation): In addition to addressing positive symptoms, atypical antipsychotics also target negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Negative symptoms involve deficits in cognitive and emotional functioning, such as social withdrawal, reduced motivation, and impaired attention. Atypical antipsychotics not only block dopamine receptors but also affect serotonin (5HT2A) receptors. This dual action is believed to contribute to their efficacy in addressing both positive and negative symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Option B: This statement is incorrect. Extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS), which include movement disorders like tremors and stiffness, are more commonly associated with typical antipsychotics. Atypical antipsychotics are designed to have a lower risk of causing EPS, making them preferable in some cases due to their better tolerability in terms of motor side effects.

Option C: It is incorrect because the metabolic side effects are more with the atypical antipsychotics as compared to typical antipsychotics.

Option D: It is incorrect, Atypical antipsychotics not only block dopamine D2 receptors but also affect serotonin 5HT2A receptors. This dual receptor antagonism is a key feature that contributes to their broader efficacy and improved side effect profile compared to typical antipsychotics.

questions.text: What is the purpose and frequency of the District Level Household Survey (DLHS), and how does it compare to the National Family Health Survey (NFHS)?

choices.text: DLHS is conducted annually to collect household data at the district level, similar to NFHS.
DLHS is conducted every 5-6 years, providing district-level details akin to NFHS but with less frequency.
DLHS is conducted biennially, offering comprehensive household data at the national level.
DLHS is conducted irregularly, with no fixed schedule, differing significantly from NFHS.

questions.solution:
Correct Options B - DLHS is conducted every 5-6 years, providing district-level details akin to NFHS but with less frequency:

  • The District Level Household Survey (DLHS) is conducted every 5-6 years to gather district-level household data, akin to the National Family Health Survey (NFHS) but with less frequency.
  • Only four rounds of DLHS have been completed to date, indicating its periodicity and highlighting that it's not conducted ad hoc but rather at regular intervals, albeit less frequently compared to NFHS.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect due to the above-given reasons

questions.text: A 13-month-old child is brought to a hospital for severe diarrhea and dermatitis. She is also underweight for her age. Physical examination shows a rash that is distributed beyond the genital area and is prevalent on knees and tissue around the mouth and anus. She has edema of hands and feet, and has alopecia. Which one of the following mineral supplements can most help relieve her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Zinc:

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder affecting zinc absorption.
  • Characterized by skin inflammation (dermatitis) and diarrhea, particularly on the cheeks, elbows, knees, and around the mouth and anus.
  • Administration of zinc with new low osmolarity oral rehydration solutions can reduce the severity and duration of diarrheal episodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lead:

  • Lead exposure leads to various symptoms including memory loss, abdominal pain, and reproductive issues.

Option B - Arsenic:

  • Arsenic toxicity affects endothelial cells and can cause various symptoms including tachycardia and cancers.

Option D - Antimony:

  • Toxicity from antimony therapy can cause respiratory irritation and skin discoloration, with potential carcinogenic effects.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with a gradual decrease in vision and glare. A slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral, linear, branching, and refractile lines in the cornea, as shown in the image below. The condition is associated with recurrent corneal erosions and may lead to corneal scarring. This presentation is characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lattice dystrophy:

  • Lattice dystrophy is characterized by the presence of linear, branching, and refractile lattice lines in the cornea as shown in the image given. These lines are visible upon slit-lamp examination. Patients with lattice dystrophy often experience a gradual decrease in vision .

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granular dystrophy: Granular dystrophy is the deposition of Hyaline in the stroma, O/E sugar granules like round opacity with a clear cornea between the opacities. It has an autosomal dominant pattern of  inheritance.

Option C - Macular dystrophy: Macular dystrophy primarily affects the central cornea and is characterized by the presence of round, grayish-white opacities, and the cornea appears hazy between the opacities. 

Option D - Schnyder crystalline dystrophy: Schnyder crystalline dystrophy is characterized by the deposition of cholesterol crystals within the cornea, leading to a cloudy appearance. It does not typically present with linear lattice lines.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman who has been known as hypertensive and diabetic for 10 years presents with a complaint of heavy vaginal bleeding. She says she had her last menstrual period 6 years ago. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in postmenopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Endometrial biopsy

  • Office endometrial aspiration biopsy is the accepted first step in evaluating a patient with abnormal uterine bleeding or suspected endometrial pathology.
  • The diagnostic accuracy of office-based endometrial biopsy is 90% to 98% when compared with subsequent findings at dilation and curettage (D&C) or hysterectomy.
  • If utilized, the hysteroscopy-guided biopsy is the best investigation for assessing the uterus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Pap smear

  • A pap smear is a screening test and is used to screen for cervical cancer.
  • For postmenopausal bleeding, a per speculum examination should be done to rule out cervical cancer, and a colposcopy biopsy must be done if cervical cancer is suspected.
  • In this case, however, the patient is hypertensive and diabetic, both of which are risk factors for endometrial cancer, which must therefore be evaluated.

Option C: Transvaginal ultrasound

  • TVS is, at best, an adjuvant that helps in the diagnosis of endometrial cancer but 'NOT' the best first step
  • Transvaginal ultrasonography may be a useful adjunct to endometrial biopsy for evaluating abnormal uterine bleeding and selecting patients for additional testing.
  • Transvaginal ultrasonography, with or without endometrial fluid instillation (sonohysterography), may help distinguish between patients with minimal endometrial tissue whose bleeding is related to perimenopausal anovulation or postmenopausal atrophy and patients with significant amounts of endometrial tissue or polyps who need further evaluation.
  • The finding of an endometrial thickness greater than 4 mm, a polypoid endometrial mass, or a collection of fluid within the uterus in a menopausal woman, requires further evaluation.

Option D: Ca-125 estimation

  • CA 125 is a tumor marker for ovarian cancer, which may be done if ovarian cancer is suspected or an ovarian mass is seen on USG.

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the tensor tympani muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cranial nerve V:

  • The tensor tympani muscle, which is one of the two intratympanic muscles in the middle ear, is supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve (Cranial nerve V).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cranial nerve VII: Facial nerve - The facial nerve does not supply the tensor tympani muscle.

Option B - Cranial nerve IX: Glossopharyngeal nerve - The glossopharyngeal nerve does not supply the tensor tympani muscle.

Option D - Cranial nerve X: Vagus nerve - The vagus nerve is not associated with the supply of the tensor tympani muscle.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 24-year-old female with high-grade fever, yellowing of skin, loss of appetite, vomiting, elevated liver enzymes, and the following histopathology findings of liver biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Acute viral hepatitis:

  • The clinical features described in the vignette and histological findings of the liver biopsy showing councilman bodies suggest a diagnosis of acute viral hepatitis
  • Acute viral hepatitis is inflammation of the liver due to a viral infection..
  • The inflammation is caused by infection with one of the five hepatitis viruses.
  • In most people, the inflammation begins suddenly and lasts only a few weeks.
  • Symptoms range from mild to severe.
  • Councilman bodies are apoptotic hepatocytes seen in acute viral hepatitis:
  • Hepatocyte apoptosis is an active form of “programmed” cell death resulting in hepatocyte shrinkage.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A- Wilson disease:

  • Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is characterised by excessive copper deposition in the tissues.
  • Investigations include slit lamp examination for Kayser-Fleischer rings and reduced serum caeruloplasmin.

Option B - Alcoholic hepatitis:

  • Alcoholic liver disease covers a spectrum of conditions:
    • Alcoholic fatty liver disease
    • Alcoholic hepatitis
    • Cirrhosis
  • Gamma-GT is characteristically raised.
  • AST:ALT is normally > 2, and a ratio of > 3 strongly indicates acute alcoholic hepatitis.

Option D- Autoimmune hepatitis:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis is a chronic, progressive hepatitis. It has three types.
  • ANA/SMA/LKM1 antibodies are seen, and there are raised IgG levels
  • Liver biopsy shows piecemeal necroses or bridging necrosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with multiple hamartomas in the skin, breast, and mucous membranes. The most common feature of this condition is multiple trichilemmomas, and the affected gene is PTEN on chromosome 10. Ectodermal and endodermal polyps are observed. Which condition is most likely to be associated with the described clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cowden's Disease:

  • Cowden's disease, also known as multiple hamartoma syndrome, is the most likely diagnosis. The key features supporting this choice include:
  1. Multiple Hamartomas
  2. Trichilemmomas
  3. The affected gene in Cowden's disease is PTEN, located on chromosome 10.
  4. Ectodermal and Endodermal Polyps
  5. Increased Risk of Malignancies

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cronkhite-Canada Syndrome:

  • Skin Pigmentary Changes: Cronkhite-Canada syndrome is associated with skin pigmentary changes, hair loss, and onychodystrophy

Option B - Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome:

  • Hamartomatous Polyps: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is characterized by hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract.

Option D - Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT):

  • Vascular Abnormalities: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia primarily involves vascular abnormalities, including telangiectasias and arteriovenous malformations.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old male with a history of TB infection comes to the orthopedic clinic due to pain and restriction near the hip region. On physical examination, the resident observed that the stance phase is shorter than the swing phase. After establishing the diagnosis, match the following features with the appropriate stage and treatment.


	
		
			
			1) Flexion, abduction, external rotation, apparent lengthening
			
			
			a) ATT, non-weight bearing ROM
			
		
		
			
			2) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation, apparent shortening
			
			
			b) Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/THR
			
		
		
			
			3) Marked flexion, adduction, internal rotation, true shortening
			
			
			c) Rest, mobilization, traction, ATT
			
		
		
			
			4) Travelling/protrusion of acetabulum
			
			
			d) Synovectomy and joint debridement
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c,2-a,3-d,4-b:

  • (Babulkar and Pandey Clinico-Radiological Classification of TB Hip Joint)

1) FABER,apparent lengthening- Stage of synovitis - c) Rest, mobilization, traction, ATT

2) FADIR,apparent shortening- Stage of early arthritis - a) ATT, non-weight bearing ROM

3) Marked FADIR,true shortening- Stage of late arthritis - d) If not relieved with ATT, non weight bearing ROM - synovectomy/joint debridement can be done

4) Travelling/protrusion of acetabulum- Stage of pathological destruction - b) Girdlestone excision arthroplasty/THR

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D:

A - 1-a,2-c,3-b,4-d

B - 1-b,2-c,3-a,4-d

D - 1-b,2-a,3-c,4-d

questions.text: All of the following are the drugs used for motion and sea sickness except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ondansetron:

  • Ondansetron is a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist and is not used for motion and sea sickness

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C:

  • These are the drugs used for motion and sea sickness

questions.text: Which neuroanatomical circuit dysfunction is primarily associated with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A : Cortico-Striatal-Thalamic-Cortical (CSTC) Circuit

  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is primarily associated with dysfunction in the Cortico-Striatal-Thalamic-Cortical (CSTC) circuit. This circuit involves several key brain regions, including the prefrontal cortex (particularly the orbitofrontal cortex), the striatum (caudate nucleus), and the thalamus. Dysfunction in this circuit leads to the characteristic symptoms of OCD.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mesolimbic Pathway is not primarily associated with OCD. The mesolimbic pathway is involved in reward and motivation and is implicated in conditions such as addiction and schizophrenia.

Option C - HPA Axis (Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal Axis) is involved in the regulation of stress response and cortisol release. While stress and cortisol dysregulation may play a role in OCD, it is not the primary neuroanatomical circuit associated with the disorder. Can be seen in depression (mood disorders).

Option D - Basal Ganglia-Thalamocortical Circuit is closely connected to the CSTC circuit and is involved in motor control and movement. While basal ganglia dysfunction has been implicated in OCD, it is more accurately described as part of the broader CSTC circuit dysfunction that underlies the disorder.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient on oral contraceptive pills complaints of intermittent abdominal pain and diarrhea for the last few months. colonoscopy reveals rectal sparing and the gross appearance of the ileum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is a specific feature related to this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Transmural involvement:

  • The description in the vignette is typical of Crohn's disease, which often involves the ileum and is characterized by the presence of superficial, broad-based ulcers.

  • Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract but commonly involves the ileum and colon.

  • Rectal sparing (the rectum is typically not affected) is a distinguishing feature of Crohn's disease, as opposed to ulcerative colitis, another form of IBD that primarily affects the colon and rectum.

  • Crohn's disease is characterized by transmural inflammation, which means it affects the entire thickness of the bowel wall.

  • The cobblestone appearance, as shown in the image in question, is a result of the transmural inflammation and the formation of skip lesions (areas of diseased bowel interspersed with normal bowel). This is a distinctive feature of Crohn's disease and distinguishes it from ulcerative colitis, which typically involves continuous mucosal inflammation without transmural involvement.

Incorrect Options: 

 

Option B - Presence of polyps: Polyps are not a defining feature of Crohn's disease but can occur in some cases.

Option C - Mucosal edema: While inflammation is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, the presence of superficial ulcers is a more specific finding. Mucosal edema may be present but is not as distinctive as the ulcers.

Option D - Superficial broad-based ulcers: Superficial broad-based ulcers are more characteristic of ulcerative colitis rather than Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman reports urine leakage from her vagina after a total abdominal hysterectomy 2 months ago. During examination, no fistula was found. After injection of methylene blue into her bladder and walking for 15 minutes, she was wet but no blue stain was found on the tampon. Which statement is true?

choices.text: 100mL was probably not enough methylene blue, and the test should be repeated with a higher volume
The patient probably has stress incontinence not a fistula
The patient probably has a ureterovaginal fistula
The patient most likely has small apical vesicovaginal fistula

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: The patient probably has a ureterovaginal fistula

  • The patient's clinical features mentioned in the above question suggest a ureterovaginal fistula, an abnormal tract between the ureter and vagina.
  • It is due to surgery complications, which the patient underwent 2 months back. To rule out the kind of fistula, a swab test is done.
  • Swabs are placed into the vagina and the patient is asked to walk around
  • Types of fistulas are mentioned in the figure below:

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 100mL was probably not enough methylene blue, and the test should be repeated with a higher volume

  • 50–100 mL of dilute methylene blue dye is enough to elicit a leak

Option B: The patient probably has stress incontinence, not a fistula.

  • Stress incontinence is the involuntary loss of urine when intravesical pressure exceeds the maximum urethral pressure with increased abdominal pressure.
  • The leak is from the urethra only on abdominal stress like coughing or sneezing. Had it been stress incontinence, only the lowermost swab may have stained with the blue dye.

Option D: The patient likely has a small apical vesicovaginal fistula 

  • The methylene blue dye stains the uppermost swab if a vesicovaginal fistula is present.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with increased risk for the complication, shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The image of the placenta shows vessels from the umbilical cord traveling within the membrane unsupported (velamentous cord), while the USG image also suggests vessels from the cord near the fetal presenting part in the lower segment.

  • Such findings are suggestive of velamentous cord with vasa previa.

Vasa previa

  • Presence of velamentous cord at the level of Internal Os.
  • Rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels lead to vaginal bleeding.
  • As it is entirely fetal blood, this may result in fetal exsanguination and even death in more than 50% of cases.
  • Diagnosis is best made by doppler

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • There is no increased risk of PROM.

Option B:

  • Vasa previa may be associated with increased risk of PPH given its association with placenta previa, but this is less likely a complication than fetal exsanguination.

Option D:

  • There is no increased risk of fetal malformations with vasa previa.

questions.text: Hospitalization for seizures post-immunization in children comes under which classification of a vaccine reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Serious reaction:

  • Any hospitalization post vaccinization comes under serious reaction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A and B: Both options are the same. They usually include local pain, fever, and redness.

Option D - Severe reaction:These reactions can be treated on an OPD basis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came to the clinic with complaints of fever, abdominal pain, and fatigue for 3 days. On examination, lower abdomen tenderness and fullness in the Pouch of Douglas were present. The doctor advised CBC which showed raised ESR, CRP, and raised leukocytes. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Clindamycin and Gentamycin:

  • Clindamycin and Gentamycin are the antibiotics used for the treatment of Endometritis
  • The condition mentioned in the scenario is Endometritis
  • It is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and dirty-smelling discharge, Fatigue, weakness
  • On examination, Lower abdomen tenderness
    • On P/Vexamination
      • Uterine and adnexal tenderness
      • Fullness in Pouch of Douglas (d/t blood collection/abscess)
    • Investigations in Endometritis
      • ↑ leucocytes on CBC
      • ↑ ESR, ↑ CRP
      • High PCT
    • Treatment
      • Clindamycin 900 mg IV every 8 hours + Gentamycin 5 mg/kg (the gold standard of therapy for endometritis)
      • Add ampicillin if sepsis is suspected

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are not used for the treatment of Endometritis

questions.text: All are true about the crib score except?

choices.text: It is the clinical risk index for babies
It is used to predict the neonatal mortality.
It compares the performance of different NICUs.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It predicts morbidity for neonates

 

Explanation:

 

The Clinical Risk Index for Babies (CRIB) is a scoring system developed to assess the initial risk of mortality in neonates, particularly those with very low birth weight. It is primarily designed to predict neonatal mortality and to facilitate comparisons of outcomes across different Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs).

While CRIB is effective in predicting mortality, its ability to predict morbidity (such as long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes) is limited. Studies have shown that CRIB scores are not significantly associated with predicting specific morbidities in neonates

 

.

It is the clinical risk index for babies (Option A): CRIB is specifically formulated to evaluate the risk of death in neonates based on clinical parameters.

It is used to predict neonatal mortality (Option B): CRIB has been validated as a reliable tool for predicting mortality in neonates, especially those born preterm or with low birth weight.

It compares the performance of different NICUs (Option C): CRIB scores can be used to adjust for the severity of illness in patient populations, allowing for more accurate comparisons of NICU performance.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with chronic anal fissures and seeks appropriate management. Which of the following interventions is NOT typically performed in the initial conservative or medical treatment of chronic anal fissures?

choices.text: Lord’s procedure – manual dilatation of sphincter

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Lord’s procedure-manual dilatation of sphincter:

  • Lord’s procedure involves manual dilatation of the anal sphincter and is usually considered a surgical intervention for chronic anal fissures. It is not typically performed in the initial conservative or medical treatment.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sitz bath with 1% potassium permanganate: Sitz bath with 1% potassium permanganate is part of the initial conservative management for chronic anal fissures.

Option B - 2% Diltiazem Gel: 2% Diltiazem Gel is a medical management and is considered a part of the initial conservative or medical treatment. 

Option C - Botox injection into sphincters: Botox injection into sphincters is a medical treatment option for chronic anal fissures. It involves the injection of botulinum toxin to relax the anal sphincter, promoting healing of the fissure.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of secondary brain injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypercapnia:

Secondary brain injury is caused by the following factors:

  • Hypoxia
  • Hypotension; Low cerebral perfusion pressure
  • ICP >20 mmHg
  • Hypercapnia
  • Metabolic disturbance (hyperglycemia)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypoglycemia:

  • Hyperglycemia has been associated with secondary brain injury, not hypoglycemia.

Option C - Hyperoxia:

  • Hypoxia has been associated with secondary brain injury, not hyperoxia.
  • Hyperoxia is a state of excess supply of O2 in tissues and organs. Oxygen toxicity occurs when the partial pressure of alveolar O2 (PAO2) exceeds that which is breathed under normal conditions. With continuous exposure to supraphysiologic concentrations of O2, a state of hyperoxia develops.

Option D - Hypertension:

  • Hypotension has been associated with secondary brain injury not hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Renal tubular acidosis?

choices.text: All Increased bicarbonates,glucose and amino acids in urine is found in RTA type 2
Urine anion gap is positive in all RTA
Nephrocalcinosis is seen in Type 4 RTA
Sodium bicarbonate is used as a treatment in all types of RTA

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Nephrocalcinosis is seen in Type 4 RTA:

  • Nephrocalcinosis is seen in Type 1 RTA and not type 4

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D

  • Urine anion gap is positive in all types of RTA
  • Sodium bicarbonate is used as a treatment in all types of RTA
  • Increased bicarbonates,glucose and amino acids in urine is found in RTA type 2

questions.text: All of the following are correct about Bioequivalence except?

choices.text: Comparison of bioavailability of 2 brands of the same drug
It is also known as generic drugs
Phenytoin follows the concept of bio-equivalence
If two brands of a drug have variation in bioavailability within an acceptable range these brands are called bioequivalent to each other

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phenytoin follows the concept of bio-equivalence:

  • This is an incorrect feature of Bio-equivalence
  • The correct feature is that Phenytoin does not follow the concept of Bioequivalence

Bio-equivalence

  • Comparison of bioavailability of 2 brands of the same drug
  • It is also known as generic drugs
  • Phenytoin does not follow the concept of bio-equivalence
  • If two brands of a drug have variation in bioavailability within an acceptable range these brands are called bioequivalent to each other

Incorrect Options

Option A B and C:

  • These are the correct features of Bioequivalence

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female presents with recent episodes of palpitations and shortness of breath. On examination, she has a systolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated anti-streptolysin O titers and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. An echocardiogram reveals moderate regurgitation in the mitral valve. A biopsy of her heart tissue is performed, and a pathology image is provided below.



Which of the following statements about this pathology is not true?

choices.text: Present in myocardium and endocardium only

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Present in myocardium and endocardium only:

  • This patient's presentation, including elevated anti-streptolysin O titers and elevated ESR with heart valve involvement, suggests the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever. The mitral and aortic valves are mostly involved, with resultant regurgitations in the acute stages of the disease. 
  • The pathology image shows a microscopic view of cardiac tissue stained with H&E (Hematoxylin and Eosin).
  • Within the myocardium, there are characteristic Aschoff bodies, which appear as granulomatous nodules containing central fibrinoid necrosis, foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages.
  • During acute RF, Aschoff bodies may be found in any of the three layers of the heart, resulting in pericarditis, myocarditis, or endocarditis (pancarditis).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fibrinoid necrosis in the center: Aschoff bodies typically show fibrinoid necrosis in the center.

Option C - Uncommon in chronic stages: Aschoff bodies are rarely seen in patients with chronic RHD because of the long intervals between the initial insult and the development of valve deformity. They are most often seen only in patients with acute RF.

Option D - Anitschkow cells: Aschoff bodies are indeed surrounded by Anitschkow cells, the plump activated macrophages that have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”).

questions.text: A skin biopsy from a patient's lesion reveals the following image. These histological findings are most characteristic of which dermatological condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Lichen planus:

  • Lichen planus is a dermatological condition characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and plaques. Histologically, lichen planus shows a "saw-tooth" pattern at the dermo-epidermal junction, which refers to a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate that dips down into the epidermis in a saw-tooth appearance. Additionally, the presence of fine, white lines or dots on the surface of the purple papules and plaques is known as Wickham's striae, which is a characteristic histological finding of lichen planus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Psoriasis: 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic skin condition characterized by well-defined, red, scaly plaques. Histologically, psoriasis typically shows acanthosis (epidermal hyperplasia), parakeratosis (retained nuclei in the stratum corneum), and Munro's microabscess, which are collections of neutrophils within the stratum corneum.

Option B- Lichen nitidus: 

  • Lichen nitidus is a benign skin condition characterized by small, discrete, flat-topped papules. Histologically, lichen nitidus shows focal lymphocytic infiltration and the presence of "clue cells" or "colloid bodies," which are cells with pale-staining nuclei lacking surrounding cytoplasm.

Option D- Pityriasis rosea: 

  • Pityriasis rosea is a self-limited skin rash that typically starts with a "herald patch" followed by the appearance of smaller, scaly, oval-shaped lesions. Histologically, pityriasis rosea shows superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient with a known history of diabetes and hypertension presents to the nephrology clinic with complaints of swelling in her legs and foamy urine over the past few weeks. Further evaluation reveals proteinuria with a 3.5 g/g urinary protein-to-creatinine ratio. Anti-PLA Antibody is positive. Which complications are most concerning for this patient based on her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Renal vein thrombosis:

  • Membranous glomerulonephritis (MGN) is a glomerular disease characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, leading to proteinuria. One of the most important complications associated with MGN is renal vein thrombosis
  • The thickening of the glomerular basement membrane can disrupt normal blood flow within the kidney, predisposing patients to the formation of blood clots in the renal veins.
  • Renal vein thrombosis can lead to further impairment of kidney function and may require aggressive management to prevent complications such as pulmonary embolism or renal infarction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute kidney injury: While acute kidney injury can occur in patients with MGN, it is not the most concerning complication associated with this condition.

Option C - Nephrotic syndrome: MGN itself is a cause of nephrotic syndrome due to significant proteinuria, but the development of renal vein thrombosis is a more serious complication.

Option D - Urinary tract infection: While urinary tract infections can occur in patients with kidney disease, they are not typically considered the most concerning complication of MGN.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Gestational period 
			
			
			Drug of choice (anticoagulants)
			
		
		
			
			1. 0-12 weeks
			
			
			a. Anticoagulant drugs not needed
			
		
		
			
			2. 12-36 weeks
			
			
			b. Warfarin(preferred), LMW/ULMW Heparin
			
		
		
			
			3. During delivery
			
			
			c. Heparin (LMWH or ULMWH)
			
		
		
			
			4. Lactation
			
			
			d. Warfarin
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1c,2d,3a,4b:

  • Drug of choice (Anticoagulants) in pregnancy:
    • Upto 12 weeks of Gestational period-
      • Heparin is DOC (LMWH or ULMWH)
      • Warfarin is contraindicated(highly teratogenic - inhibits organ formation)

                                              Warfarin in fetus

                                                        ↓

                                          Inhibit Vitamin K

                                                        ↓

                                              ↓↓osteocalcin

                                                        ↓

                                  Bone and Cartilage defect in fetus

                                       K/s fetal warfarin syndrome

                                      K/s Chondrodysplasia punctata

    • From 12 -36 weeks - DOC: Warfarin
    • From 36 weeks to 1 day before delivery - DOC: LMW/ULMWH
    • During delivery-
      • No anticoagulant drugs are recommended
      • Increases postpartum hemorrhage
    • In the lactation period- Warfarin (preferred), LMW/ULMW Heparin
    • Antidotes
      • Warfarin: Vitamin K1
      • HMW heparin: Protamine sulfate

Match the following serum studies with their respective disorders.:

questions.text: The muscle marked in green coloured is supplied by which nerve?
questions.solution:
Option D: Subcostal nerve

  • The muscle shown in the picture is pyramidalis.
  • It originates from the anterior surface of the pubis and is inserted in the linea alba.
  • The main action of pyramidal is to the tenses linea alba.
  • The 12th Thoracic nerve (subcostal nerve) supplies the following muscles
  1. Pyramidalis
  2. Rectus abdominis
  3. Intercostal muscles
  4. Anterior abdominal wall muscles.

Option A: Ilioinguinal nerve

  • It originates from the anterior rami of the T12 and L1 nerve roots.
  • It supplies sensory innervations to the anterior surface of the scrotum in males or labia majora in females, the root of the penis or mons pubis, and some parts of the medial thigh.
  • It innervates the following muscles:
  1. Internal oblique
  2. Transversus abdominis muscles

Option B: Iliohypogastric nerve

  • It originates from the lumbar plexus.
  • It gives sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral gluteal and hypogastric regions.
  • It supplies its motor innervation to the following muscles:
  1. ​​​​​​​Internal oblique muscles
  2. Transverse abdominal muscles.

Option C: Genitofemoral nerve

  • It provides sensory supply to the upper thigh region.
  • It supplies the mons pubis and labia majora in females and the skin of the anterior scrotum in males.
  • It supplies its motor innervation to the cremaster muscle.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset sharp chest pain on the left side and hemodynamic instability. He reports no recent trauma or heavy lifting. On examination, decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on percussion are noted on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray is given below:



What is the next best step of management for this case?

choices.text: Observation with serial chest X-rays and supplemental oxygen therapy.
Administration of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain control and reassessment in 24 hours.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Needle Decompression:

  • The patient's presentation, including sudden-onset sharp chest pain, decreased breath sounds, and hyperresonance on percussion, suggests a tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition wherein increased intrapleural pressure leads to cardiomediastinal compression and displacement and reduction in venous return resulting in hemodynamic instability. Needle decompression is the immediate intervention of choice to release trapped air in the pleural space, alleviate pressure on the affected lung, and stabilize the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhalational Corticosteroids:

  • Inhalational corticosteroids are not indicated in the management of pneumothorax. They are typically used in asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Option B - Observation with Serial Chest X-rays and Supplemental Oxygen Therapy:

  • Observation and serial chest X-rays are not ideal for managing a symptomatic pneumothorax. Immediate interventions are required rather than observation.

Option C - Administration of Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) for Pain Control and Reassessment in 24 Hours:

  • NSAIDs do not address the underlying issue of trapped air in the pleural space. The patient requires a more definitive intervention with chest tube placement.

questions.text: A newborn of 2 weeks following a normal vaginal delivery presents to the hospital with complaints of discharge, swelling, and redness of the eyes, along with seizures. On examination, the doctor finds that the patient has increased head circumference and chorioretinitis. Labs showed a crescent-shaped parasite in the CSF on Giemsa staining, and CT of the brain showed the following finding. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Toxoplasma gondii:

  • The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus.
  • The combination of clinical manifestations, including chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and mental retardation, along with the presence of intracerebral calcifications and enlarged ventricles on the CT, is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.
  • Toxoplasma gondii, a protozoan parasite, can cause severe neurological sequelae when transmitted from a pregnant mother to her fetus. The risk of fetal infection rises with the gestational age.
    • 1st trimester - 25% chances of infection with severe manifestation of the disease.
    • 2nd trimester - 65% chances of infection with mild manifestation or may be asymptomatic.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

  • Congenital CMV infection can cause a range of clinical manifestations, including sensorineural hearing loss, microcephaly, and developmental delays.
  • CMV infection can lead to periventricular calcifications in the brain, which is a key distinguishing feature from other congenital infections.
  • The clinical presentation in the question, including cerebral calcifications and specific symptoms, does not match typical congenital CMV infection.

Option C - Rubella virus:

  • Congenital rubella syndrome can lead to a triad of congenital heart defects, cataracts, and sensorineural deafness.
  • The clinical presentation and findings in the question do not match the typical manifestations of congenital rubella syndrome.

Option D - Herpes simplex virus:

  • Congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can present with skin lesions, central nervous system involvement, and disseminated disease.
  • It is not commonly associated with cerebral calcifications and convulsions as described in the question.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of persistent hoarseness of voice for the past six weeks. He denies any significant cough, throat pain, or difficulty swallowing. He has a history of smoking for the past 30 years. On examination, there is an ulcer on the left vocal cord. Which is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Biopsy and HPE:

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of glottic carcinoma. A biopsy followed by histopathological examination is the investigation of choice for diagnosing laryngeal carcinomas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contrast-enhanced CT scan: CECT scan is the initial investigation done for laryngeal carcinoma, but it is not the investigation of choice for confirming malignancy.

Option B - MRI scan: MRI scan can give accurate information about cartilage involvement, but it is not the investigation of choice for confirming laryngeal malignancy.

Option D - PET scan: PET scans are not the investigation of choice for confirming laryngeal malignancy.

questions.text:
The following are various bone deformities associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Match them accordingly.


	
		
			
			1) Swan neck deformity
			
			
			a)

			
			
		
		
			
			2) Buttonhole deformity
			
			
			b)

			
			
		
		
			
			3) Hitchhiker’s deformity
			
			
			c)

			
			
		
		
			
			4) Z deformity
			
			
			d)

			
			
		
		
			
			5) Windswept deformity
			
			
			e)

			f)
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-c, 2-f, 3-e, 4-b, 5-a, 6-d

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d, 5-f, 6-e

questions.text: Among the following options, which of the following is common to both CCK and gastrin?

choices.text: Secretion is stimulated by fatty acids

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trophic action:

  • Gastrin stimulates mucosal growth (trophic action) of the stomach.
  • CCK exerts a trophic effect on the pancreas.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secreted by I-cells:

  • CCK is secreted by I-cells, while gastrin is secreted by G-cells.

Option C - Increases gastric emptying;

  • Gastrin increases while CCK decreases gastric emptying.

Option D - Secretion is stimulated by fatty acids:

  • The primary stimulus for the secretion of gastrin is the presence of certain foodstuffs, especially peptides, certain amino acids, and calcium, in the gastric lumen.
  • Cholecystokinin is secreted by cells of the upper small intestine. Its secretion is stimulated by the introduction of hydrochloric acid, amino acids, or fatty acids into the duodenum.

questions.text: A worker from Bihar has recently been hired in the aluminum industry. After returning from his hometown, he developed fever, chills, sweating, and fatigue. After a thorough evaluation, he was diagnosed with an infection and quinine was prescribed by the physician. An image of the vector transmitting the infection is given. Which of the following is not a feature of this vector?

choices.text: It sits at an angle of 45⁰
The head is downwards- resting in an inclined position
Eggs are round-shaped with lateral floats

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Eggs are round-shaped with lateral floats:

  • This statement is incorrect for Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • The clinical scenario is about a patient who developed malaria, caused by Plasmodium. The vector for Plasmodium is the Anopheles mosquito.
  • Anopheles mosquito eggs are not round-shaped.
  • Instead, they are laid singly on the water surface and have a unique appearance with a boat shape and lateral floats.
  • This feature of having round-shaped eggs with lateral floats is characteristic of the Culex mosquito eggs, which are laid in rafts that float on the water.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It sits at an angle of 45⁰:

  • This is true for the Anopheles mosquito.
  • When resting, the body of an Anopheles mosquito, including its proboscis, thorax, and abdomen, makes an angle of 45 degrees with the surface.
  • This is a distinctive behavior that helps differentiate it from other mosquitoes.

Option B - The head is downwards - resting in an inclined position:

  • This statement is true.
  • This feature helps with the identification of the Anopheles mosquito.

Option C - It has spotted wings:

  • This is true for the Anopheles.
  • This is a key differentiating feature of Anopheles mosquitoes.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Maximum tolerated dose
			
			
			A
			
			
			Phase 1
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Randomized control trial
			
			
			B
			
			
			Phase 2
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Monitor rare side effects
			
			
			C
			
			
			Phase 3
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Maximum drug failure
			
			
			D
			
			
			Phase 4
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-A, 2-C, 3-D, 4-B:

  • Phases of clinical trials:

Phase 0
  • Tested on Healthy Human
  • Up to 10 participants
  • Micro dosing: 1/100 of a dose because high doses may be fateful

Phase 1
  • Also tested on Healthy Human Volunteers
  • Extends from months to year (10-100)
  • Safety and Nontoxicity profile of drugs
  • Maximum tolerated dose of a drug (beyond this adverse effects of a drug occur )

Phase 2
  • Tested on Patients
  • 50-500 participants
  • Lasts for 1-2 years
  • Effectiveness and Efficacy
  • Maximum drug failure always occurs in Phase 2

Phase 3
  • Patients can be 500-3000 in number
  • This phase lasts 3-5 years
  • Comparison with existing drugs
  • Randomized Control Trial

 

Phase 4
  • Also tested on Patients
  • The study is unending till the drug removal
  • Longest phase (at least till 10-25 years)
  • Monitor Long-term and rare side effects
  • Post - marketing surveillance

 

Incorrect  Options: 

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
In the graph below, Curve A is obtained for liver glucokinase, while Curve B is for muscle glucokinase under similar conditions.

 



Which is the correct statement regarding the relationship between these enzymes?

choices.text: A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor
B has a greater affinity for glucose than A.
At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics.
B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A:

  • B has a higher Michaelis-Menten constant (Km) than A.
  • Km is determined from substrate concentration at half of enzyme's Vmax.

  • The graph indicates B's higher Km as it has higher Vmax compared to A.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A is the same enzyme as B but in the presence of a competitive inhibitor:

  • A is the same enzyme as B but with a competitive inhibitor. If so, both would have equal Vmax, contrary to the graph.

Option B - B has a greater affinity for glucose than A:

  • B has greater glucose affinity than A. Affinity relates to lower Km; hence, A's lower Km implies higher affinity for glucose.

Option C - At maximal substrate concentrations, both enzymes display first-order kinetics:

  • Both enzymes display first-order kinetics at maximal substrate concentrations. Yet, at this point, enzyme binding sites are saturated, suggesting zero-order kinetics, not first-order.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with mucosal bleeding, nasal obstruction, and mild breathing difficulty for over two weeks. Physical examination reveals swelling at the left part of the nose and painless lymph node enlargement over 5 cm in diameter. Skin biopsy shows macrophages containing amastigotes as ovoid inclusions microscopically, leading to a diagnosis of mucocutaneous leishmaniasis. What is the causative agent for this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Leishmania braziliensis:

  • Mucosal Leishmaniasis is a form of tegumentary Leishmaniasis, which is most likely associated with L.braziliensis and L.panamensis.
  • Classically it is characterized by well-defined ulcers with elevated borders.
  • Lymph node enlargement is usually painless or mildly painful, found in the groin, the crural region and least likely in the popliteal region.
  • Most of the ulcers caused by L.braziliensis are located in the lower limb region.
  • In L.braziliensis transmission regions, about 3% of cutaneous leishmaniasis patients, after disease remission, develop a mucosal form of the disease called espundia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - L. Tropica:

  • It causes cutaneous Leishmaniasis and results in non-ulcerating lesions.
  • Mostly found in Asia and Africa.

Option C - L. donovani:

  • It causes Visceral Leishmaniasis, also known as Kala-azar (black fever).
  • It usually presents with flu-like symptoms, spiking fever, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, ascites, edema, pancytopenia and darkened skin.
  • Amphotericin B is preferred monotherapy.

Option D - L. orientalis:

  • A parasite from Thailand responsible for localized cutaneous Leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who collapsed was rushed to the Emergency department for rescue. The ECG was taken and is shown below. The doctor started resuscitation and failed even after giving several cycles of CPR and defibrillation attempts, and epinephrine administration. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Advanced airway:

  • The ECG shows ventricular fibrillation which is a shockable rhythm.
  • The doctor tried to give several cycles of CPR and defibrillation attempts, but failed and started administering epinephrine which showed no improvement.
  • The next step in management is securing an advanced airway and capnography

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 3rd non-synchronized DC shock given: Only when advanced airway fails

Option C -  IV Amiodrone: This is administered when even a third round of shock fails

Option D - Targeted temperature management: This is done if Return of spontaneous circulation (R.O.S.C) is achieved

questions.text: A 55-year-old female complained of chest pain for 1 hour associated with shortness of breath and low-grade fever. She has a history of anterior wall myocardial infarction 6 weeks ago, which was treated with fibrinolytic therapy. On examination, elevated JVP and a friction rub in the 5th intercostal space are noted. ECG shows diffuse ST elevation with PR depression. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  Dressler syndrome:

  • Dressler syndrome, also known as postmyocardial infarction syndrome, is a complication of myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery.

  • It results from an autoimmune inflammatory reaction to antigens of the myocardium.

  • It is a fibrinous pericarditis

  • It presents 2-3 weeks after myocardial infarction with the following clinical features:

    • Low-grade fever

    • Pleuritic chest pain

    • Friction rub

    • Diffuse ST elevation with PR depression

  • Treatment includes corticosteroids and aspirin.

  • Dressler syndrome is an inflammatory condition involving the pericardium (the membrane around the heart) that occurs after myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery. It typically presents weeks to months after the initial event. The symptoms often include chest pain, fever, pleuritic pain, and sometimes pericardial friction rub. Elevated JVP can occur due to impaired filling of the heart caused by pericardial effusion (fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac).

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Myocardial rupture:

  • Myocardial rupture usually occurs as left ventricular wall rupture, leading to cardiac tamponade and hemopericardium.

  • It occurs 3-7 days after MI and presents with chest pain, elevated JVP, and reduced heart sounds.

Option B - Papillary muscle dysfunction:

  • Papillary muscle dysfunction leads to mitral valve regurgitation and insufficiency.

  • Patients would present with palpitations and cardiac murmurs.

  • Friction rub and elevated JVP are not signs of mitral valve regurgitation.

Option D - Ventricular aneurysm:

  • Ventricular aneurysms are a late complication of MI.

  • They lead to the formation of mural thrombi, arrhythmias, and heart failure but do not rupture.

  • Friction rub and elevated JVP are not seen.

questions.text:
A group of researchers from the Institute of Medical Sciences community medicine department are involved in a study about various diseases transmitted by lice. Given in the table is a list of bacteria and a louse. Match them with the disease caused by them appropriately.


	
		
			
			Causative Agent
			
			
			Disease Transmitted
			
		
		
			
			1. Rickettsia quintana
			
			
			a. Pediculosis
			
		
		
			
			2. Borrelia recurrentis
			
			
			b. Trench fever
			
		
		
			
			3. Rickettsia prowazekii
			
			
			c. Relapsing fever
			
		
		
			
			4. Head louse-scalp
			
			
			d. Epidemic typhus
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1-b,2-c,3-d,4-a:

1. Rickettsia Quintana: 

  • This bacterium is responsible for causing Trench fever, a disease characterized by recurrent episodes of fever, headache, and muscle pain. 
  • It is transmitted to humans primarily by the body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis), which serves as a vector. 
  • Trench fever was notably observed during World War I among soldiers living in crowded and unhygienic conditions in trenches, hence the name.

2. Borrelia Recurrentis: 

  • This spirochete bacterium is the causative agent of Relapsing fever, an infectious disease characterized by recurring episodes of fever, chills, headache, and muscle aches. 
  • It is transmitted to humans through the bite of ticks. 
  • These ticks are often found in rodent-infested buildings, caves, and other dwellings, especially in regions with poor sanitation and hygiene.

3. Rickettsia Prowazekii: 

  • This bacterium causes Epidemic typhus, a severe febrile illness characterized by high fever, headache, rash, and other systemic symptoms. 
  • It is transmitted to humans through the bites of infected body lice (Pediculus humanus humanus). Epidemic typhus has been associated with crowded and unsanitary living conditions, such as those seen in refugee camps and during times of war or social upheaval.

4. Head Louse: 

  • Pediculosis is the infestation of lice, particularly the head louse (Pediculus humanus capitis), which affects the scalp. 
  • Head lice infestations are common, especially among school-aged children, and can lead to itching and discomfort. 
  • While head lice themselves do not transmit diseases directly, their presence can lead to secondary bacterial infections from scratching and can cause significant social stigma.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - 1-a,2-c,3-a,4-d

Options C - 1-b,2-a,3-c,4-d

Options D - 1-c,2-a,3-d,4-b

  • These do not indicate the correct match between the causative agent and the disease.

questions.text: What contributes to the generation of the fourth heart sound in the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vibration of ventricular wall:

  • The fourth heart sound occurs after the AV valves open during rapid ventricular filling.
  • It occurs due to the vibration of the ventricular wall or the vibration of the blood in the ventricular cavity.
  • It occurs during the last rapid filling phase (LRFP) due to atrial contraction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Closure of the atrioventricular valves:

  • The S4 sound is not associated with atrioventricular valve closure.

Option B - Opening of the tricuspid valve:

  • The S4 sound is not associated with not tricuspid valve opening.

Option C - Opening of the atrioventricular valves::

  • The fourth heart sound (S4) is not associated with atrioventricular valves.

questions.text:
Assertion: In most nursing mothers, the ovarian cycle does not resume until a few weeks.

Reason: Prolactin secretion during sucking inhibits the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus.

Which of the following conclusions about the assertion and the reason are true?

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for assertion
Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for assertion
Assertion is an independently true/correct statement, but the reason is an independently false/incorrect statement
Assertion is an independently false/incorrect statement, but the reason is an independently true/correct statement

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for assertion:

  • During sucking, prolactin is released from the pituitary, which gives negative feedback to the hypothalamus for the secretion of GnRH; thus, FSH and LH are decreased.
  • Thus, the ovarian cycle is inhibited in nursing mothers.
  • Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for assertion

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, but reason is not the correct explanation for assertion

Option C - Assertion is an independently true/correct statement, but the reason is an independently false/incorrect statement

Option D - Assertion is an independently false/incorrect statement, but the reason is an independently true/correct statement

  • Both statements are independently true.
  • The reason suckling increases the prolactin release is the true depiction of the absence of menstruation during lactation.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents with complaints of high fever, difficulty swallowing and a history of sore throat. On examination, the child is sitting in the following position:



Which pathogen is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Haemophilus influenzae

The patient is sitting in  TRIPOD position, with complaints of high fever, difficulty swallowing, and a history of sore throat which indicates epiglottitis.

: Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) is the most common cause of acute epiglottitis in children.

Incorrect Options:

Option B -Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus can cause various infections, including skin and soft tissue infections, pneumonia, and bacteremia, it is not typically associated with the classic presentation of epiglottitis

Option C - Parainfluenza virus: Parainfluenza virus is not commonly associated with acute epiglottitis.

Option D - Influenza virus: Influenza virus is not typically associated with acute epiglottitis. It is caused secondary to bacterial infections.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures form the floor of the triangle marked below?



Which of the following structures form the floor of the triangle marked above?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Internal Oblique:

  • The triangle marked above is the Lumbar triangle of Petit. It is a triangular space present in the posterolateral part of the lumbar region.
  • The boundaries of the triangle of Petit are:
    • Inferiorly: iliac crest
    • Superiorly: the apex of the triangle
    • Anteriorly: external oblique muscle
    • Posteriorly: latissimus dorsi muscle
  • The floor of the Petit triangle is formed by the internal oblique muscle, which is marked in the diagram shown in the question.
  • Following are the potential sites of hernia in the lateral abdominal wall:

Types of Lateral abdominal wall hernias

Location

Inferior lumbar hernia

Triangle of Petit

Superior lumbar hernia

Superior lumbar triangle (Grynfeltt-Lesshaft triangle). It is bounded by the 12th rib, erector spinae, and internal oblique muscles.

Lumbar incisional hernia

Following surgery involving the posterolateral abdominal wall

Spigelian hernia

Along the semilunar line
  • The following diagram labels the structures shown in the diagram in the question:

  • The triangle of Petit is an area of potential weakness; therefore, it can be a site of hernias. The hernias that occur through this triangle are known as lumbar hernias or Petit’s hernias.

Option A: Erector spinae

  • The erector spinae is a group of muscles that extends from the sacrum to the skull on the sides of the spinous processes of the vertebra. They do not form the floor of the lumbar triangle of the Petit.

Option C: Rectus abdominis

  • The rectus abdominis is in the front midline of the body wall, extending from the pubic symphysis to the xiphoid process and rib cage. It does not form the floor of the lumbar triangle of Petit.

Option D: Fascia transversalis

  • The fascia transversalis forms the posterior lamina of the rectus sheath. It does not form the floor of the lumbar triangle of Petit.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, with uncontrolled diabetes and recent COVID history treated with steroids, presents with bulging eyes, decreased vision, and eye pain. Examination reveals proptosis and necrotic areas with black eschar on the nasal septum. SDA culture shows growth below. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mucormycosis:

  • The patient's history of uncontrolled diabetes, recent COVID-19 recovery with steroid use, proptosis, pain, decreased vision, black eschar on the nasal septum, and grey-white with cottony, fluffy surface colonies are indicative of a fungal infection, specifically mucormycosis caused by rhizopus or mucor.

  • Infection typically starts in the sinuses and progresses into the orbital cavity, with a tendency to invade vessels and cause ischemic necrosis.

  • Increased risk of infection in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis or immunocompromised conditions and on steroid therapy.

  • Most patients present with severe pain, proptosis, and necrotic areas, often accompanied by black eschar on the palate and nasal septum.
  • Diagnosis: The biopsy tissue of the involved area is sent for microbiological confirmation.
    • Direct microscopy by 10% KOH mount: Reveals nonseptate broad branching hyphae
    • Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar reveals grey-white cottony, fluffy surface colonies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bacterial conjunctivitis: Bacterial conjunctivitis is an infection of the conjunctiva, the thin tissue covering the white part of the eye. It typically presents with symptoms like redness, discharge, and discomfort.

Option B - Ocular candidiasis: Ocular candidiasis is caused by Candida albicans, a yeast species known for causing fungal infections, such as oral thrush and vaginal yeast infections.  Candida albicans on SDA form white to cream-coloured, smooth, glabrous, and yeast-like colonies.

Option C - Microsporidial infection​​​​​​​: Microsporidial infection is caused by microsporidia spp. commonly affecting immunocompromised patients. It manifests as diarrhoea, conjunctival hyperemia, punctate epithelial keratitis, necrotizing keratitis, and corneal ulcer. Detected by microscopic examination of the stool usinf trichrome stain. These are cultured on the mammalian cell lines.

questions.text: A marriage can be declared as null and void in all of the following situations except:

choices.text: If the partner’s mental illness was present at the time of marriage
If the partner’s mental illness was present after the time of marriage
If the partner’s mental illness was present only before the time of marriage

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - If the partner’s mental illness was present only before the time of marriage: 

  • If the partner’s mental illness was present only before the time of marriage, the marriage cannot be declared null and void.

Incorrect Options:

Option A/ B -  If the partner’s mental illness was present at the time of marriage/ If the partner’s mental illness was present after the time of marriage: The mental condition of both the parties at the time of marriage is taken for deciding nullification.

questions.text: A 7-month-old infant was brought to you with a history of hypotonia, seizures, failure to thrive & growth retardation. He is noted to have the appearance of the characteristic sparse, fragile, kinky hair and hypo-pigmented skin. Initial investigations revealed anaemia & neutropenia. A probable diagnosis of Menke’s kinky (Steely) hair disease was made. Which of the following results would usually be seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low copper levels.

  • Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disease that occurs due to a mutation in the ATP7A gene leading to defective Menkes protein.
  • The defective Menkes protein causes abnormal absorption and transport of copper.
  • Low copper levels lead to decreased lysyl oxidase activity, as copper is an essential enzyme cofactor.
  • The decreased activity of lysyl oxidase causes defective collagen production, leading to various clinical features.

Clinical Features

  • Progressive cerebral degeneration, growth retardation.
  • Hypotonia, seizures.
  • Hypo-pigmented skin and hair.
  • Sparse, brittle, kinky hair.
  • Scurvy-like bone changes.
  • Anemia and neutropenia.
  • Failure to thrive.
  • Pili torti, trichorrhexis, and monilethrix may occur.

Other options

Option B: Low zinc levels

  • Low zinc levels do not cause Menkes disease.
  • Symptoms of low zinc levels include delayed wound healing, suppressed immunity, male hypogonadism, hair loss, and loss of taste and smell.

Option C: Low iron levels

  • Low iron levels do not cause Menkes disease.
  • It causes iron deficiency anaemia as fatigue, conjunctival pallor, koilonychia and pica.

Option D: Low ceruloplasmin levels

  • Low ceruloplasmin is seen in Wilson’s disease and not in Menkes disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for the functioning of a countercurrent system?

choices.text: The movement of the fluid in the tubes should be in the same direction
Tubes should be in close proximity to each other

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The movement of the fluid in the tubes should be in the same direction:

  • There are four conditions required for the countercurrent system to function.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the advanced molecular mechanism of action of the following substance?

choices.text: Modulates contrast in tumors situated within the blood-brain barrier (BBB)

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Alters T1 relaxation: Magnevist (gadolinium-based contrast agent) primarily acts by increasing T1 relaxation during magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). When gadolinium is administered, it shortens the T1 relaxation time of nearby protons, leading to enhanced signal intensity in T1-weighted images. This increased contrast helps in visualizing structures like blood vessels and enhancing the visibility of certain pathological conditions in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Induces signal decay:

  • Gadolinium-based contrast agents, like Magnevist, primarily affect T1 relaxation rather than inducing signal decay. They are known to increase signal intensity in T1-weighted images.

Option B- Reverse-phase contrast:

  • Magnevist is not a reverse-phase contrast. It primarily induces positive contrast.

Option D- Modulates contrast in tumors situated within the blood-brain barrier (BBB):

  • While gadolinium contrast is used to enhance the visualization of tumors, it is limited to only those which lie outside the blood-brain barrier (BBB).

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presented with complaints of pain, fatigue, and paresthesia in his left arm for the last nine months. The patient also had dizziness for the past six months, which worsen with upper-extremity activity or exercise. The patient had a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. On physical examination, there is a systolic bruit in the left supraclavicular fossa. Vital signs are include blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg, pulse pressure of 65/min and respiration rate of 18/min. Coronal magnetic resonance is ordered, which reveals the following finding as shown in the image:



 What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Subclavian steal syndrome:

  • This is a case of subclavian steal syndrome with pain, fatigue, paresthesia in the left arm, dizziness, disequilibrium, and supraclavicular bruit.
  • It occurs due to atherosclerosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery, leading to a reversal of blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery.
  • Diagnosis
    • Doppler ultrasound
    • Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA)
  • Treatment
    • Lipid-lowering intervention
    • Smoking cessation
    • Stent placement in some cases

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Angina:

  •  Angina is chest pain due to ischemic myocardium secondary to coronary artery narrowing or spasm.
  •  Atherosclerosis is the most common risk factor and doesn't lead to cardiac myocyte necrosis.
  • ECG findings are ST depression (stable angina), transient ST elevation (vasospastic angina) and ST depression and T wave inversion (unstable angina)

Option C - Aortic dissection:

  • Aortic dissection is an intima tear that occurs in the proximal 10 cm of the aorta with pre-existing weakness of tunica media.
  • It is associated with risk factors like a bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension, Marfan syndrome, and cocaine use.

Option D - Heart failure:

  • Heart failure is a failure of the cardiac pump that presents with shortness of breath, orthopnea, fatigue, crackles, S3 heart sound, jugular venous distention, and pitting edema.
  • Left heart failure is caused by hypertension, myocardial infarction, ischemia, and dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • A right heart failure is caused by left heart failure, chronic lung disease (leads to cor pulmonale)

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents with malaise and a painful swelling on her back. On examination, there is an abscess with multiple draining sinuses and an infected mass lying beneath. The lesion appears red with a whitish-yellow center. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Staphylococcus aureus:

  • A carbuncle is an infection of the hair follicles that extends into the surrounding skin and underlying subcutaneous tissue.

  • They typically present as an erythematous, tender, inflamed, fluctuant nodule with multiple draining sinus tracts or pustules on the surface.
  • Bacterial infection within the hair follicle causes carbuncles.
  • The most common causative organism is the gram-positive bacterium Staphylococcus aureus, which frequently involves methicillin-resistant S aureus.

Incorrect Options:
Option A- Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes is a gram-positive organism responsible for skin infections such as erysipelas (characterized by a well-demarcated and raised area of erythema) and cellulitis (characterized by a poorly demarcated, warm, erythematous area with associated edema and tenderness).

Erysipelas Cellulitis

Option B- Pseudomonas aeruginosa: It predominantly causes erythema gangrenosum, which is characterized by erythematous, ulcerated, purple, or black skin lesions in the axillary, inguinal, or anogenital areas.

Option C- Candida albicans: Intertrigo is a superficial inflammatory skin condition of the skin's flexural surfaces, prompted or irritated by warm temperatures, friction, moisture, maceration, and poor ventilation. Candida albicans secondarily infects intertrigo.

questions.text: What is the effect on end-systolic volume (ESV) during exercise within the physiological limit?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ESV decreases:

  • An increased sympathetic discharge during exercise has a positive inotropic effect on the heart.
  • LV contractility increases, ejecting a greater stroke volume (SV).
  • Hence, there is a decrease in ESV, as shown in the image.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - ESV increases: During exercise, stroke volume increases, decreasing the end-systolic volume due to increased sympathetic supply. ESV volume would usually increase in conditions where the heart contractility is reduced as in heart failure, or in cases of aortic regurgitation

Option C - ESV remains unchanged: End systolic volume changes; as discussed above, it decreases.

Option D - ESV first decreases, then increases: It only decreases, not fluctuate.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of inability to open his jaw completely, along with stiffness in his neck for the past five days and a history of tonsillitis. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling on the right side of the neck.



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Parapharyngeal abscess:

  • The presentation of inability to fully open the jaw, neck stiffness, and tenderness and swelling on the right side of the neck, in conjunction with a history of tonsillitis and puss point seen behind the posterior pillar, is highly suggestive of a parapharyngeal abscess.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prevertebral abscess: Prevertebral abscess is present in the midline.

Option B - Peritonsillar abscess: Peritonsillar abscess does not present with a neck swelling.

D/D of Unilateral Bulge of Tonsil

questions.text:
Match the disorders with the underlying defects:


	
		
			1. Familial Hyperchylomicronemia
			a. Defect in Apo A-II
		
		
			2. Familial Hypercholesterolemia
			b. Defect in Apo C-II
		
		
			3. Familial combined Hyperlipoproteinemia
			c. Defect in Apo-E
		
		
			4. Dyslipoproteinemia
			d. Increase in VLDL and LDL
		
		
			 
			e. Defect in LCAT
		
		
			 
			f. Autosomal Dominant
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1b, 2f, 3d, 4c:

It is the correct matching order.

Familial Hyperchylomicronemia

  • Autosomal recessive disorder
  • Absence of Apo C-II or lipoprotein lipase
  • Elevated chylomicrons with massive triglycerides
  • Clinical features: eruptive xanthoma, hepatosplenomegaly, lipemia retinalis, bile duct stenosis
  • Presents in children with colicky pain and symptoms of failure to thrive
  • Triggers: estrogen use, pregnancy

 Familial Hypercholesterolemia:

  • It's an autosomal dominant disease.
  • Defective LDL receptors or mutation in ligand region of apo B-100.
  • LDL receptor deficiency leads to a high level of Cholesterol and LDL.
  • Increased risk of atherosclerosis, coronary artery disease, ischemic heart disease
  • Clinical features: xanthoma of Achilles tendon, tuberous xanthoma, xanthelasma, corneal arcus

Familial combined Hyperlipoproteinemia:

  • Defective LDL receptor or B-100.
  • LDL and VLDL lipoprotein defect.
  • Total cholesterol LDL and VLDL is increased, and triglycerides are also increased.
  • Genetic disorder predisposing to high VLDL and LDL levels, exacerbated by alcohol, diabetes, hypothyroidism

Dyslipoproteinemia:

  • It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • It has defective Apo-E.
  • It also increases the risk of atherosclerosis and has palmer and tuberoeruptive xanthomas.
  • Cholesterol, chylomicrons, and VLDL are increased.
