questions.text: A 60-year-old man at the ophthalmology clinic reports gradual central vision loss in both eyes, possibly due to medication. His fundoscopic appearance is shown in the picture below. What medication could be causing this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hydroxychloroquine:

  • Associated with bull's eye maculopathy as a well-known adverse effect.
  • Commonly used for managing rheumatologic and dermatologic conditions like lupus and arthritis.
  • Deposits in the eye's macula, leading to characteristic retinal changes.
  • Monitoring for ocular side effects crucial for early detection and prevention of vision loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prednisone: A corticosteroid medication not linked to bull's eye maculopathy.

Option B - Aspirin: An antiplatelet and analgesic medication without significant ocular side effects.

Option D - Atorvastatin: A statin medication for lipid management, not associated with bull's eye maculopathy.

questions.text: A patient presents with painless burn characterized by dry and leathery skin, extending from the wrist to the elbow. What is the most appropriate initial management for this burn?

choices.text: Application of a topical antibiotic ointment
Daily dressing changes with sterile saline

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Immediate surgical debridement and grafting:

  • Burns characterized by dry and leathery skin, known as full-thickness (third-degree) burns, indicate significant damage to the skin layers, including nerve endings.
  • Painlessness suggests nerve injury and deep tissue damage.
  • Immediate surgical debridement and grafting are crucial to remove dead tissue (debridement) and replace it with healthy skin (grafting) to promote wound healing and prevent complications such as infection.
  • This approach helps in restoring function and aesthetics and reduces the risk of complications associated with full-thickness burns.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Application of a topical antibiotic ointment:

  • Topical antibiotic ointments are not suitable for full-thickness burns as they cannot penetrate the deep tissue layers affected by the burn.
  • These burns require surgical intervention rather than topical treatment alone.

Option C- Administration of intravenous antibiotics:

  • Intravenous antibiotics are not the primary treatment for burns, especially full-thickness burns, unless there are signs of infection.
  • Initial management should focus on addressing tissue damage and preventing infection through surgical intervention.

Option D- Daily dressing changes with sterile saline:

  • Daily dressing changes with sterile saline may be part of the wound care regimen after surgical debridement and grafting.
  • However, it is not the most appropriate initial management for a full-thickness burn extending from the wrist to the elbow.

questions.text: A 3-month-old is presented to the clinic for abnormal features by his parents. He has a hump on his back, his chest is protruding, and he has a broad forehead. His X-ray of the wrist and spine is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Morquio disease

  • Morquio syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type IV [MPS IV]) is a rare lysosomal storage disorder (LSD) that is inherited in autosomal dominant traits.
  • Morquio syndrome is distinguished by a distinct skeletal dysplasia caused by an abnormal buildup of keratan sulfate (KS) and chondroitin-6-sulfate (C6S). Although most Morquio syndrome patients seem normal at birth, skeletal abnormalities frequently emerge within the first year of life. Some affected neonates may have a modest skeletal phenotype at birth, such as a humpback, chest protrusion, and broad forehead, which can be verified by radiography.
  • The bony abnormalities seen in the X-ray, i.e. bullet-shaped metacarpals and beaked vertebral bodies, comprise 'dysostosis multiplex', characteristic of Morquio disease.

Option A: Gaucher disease

  • Gaucher's disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disease.
  • It occurs due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency, which causes glucocerebroside to build up inside the lysosomes of cells.
  • The patient usually presents with hepatosplenomegaly, bone aches, pathologic fractures, bruising (thrombocytopenia), and anaemia.
  • Neurological characteristics may or may not exist.
  • On an X-ray of the long bone, Erlenmeyer flask deformity may be visible.

Option B: Fabry disease

  • Fabry disease is an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease (LSD).
  • It occurs due to a deficiency of α-galactosidase enzymes in the lysosomes.
  • Ceramide trihexoside (globotriaosylceramide) accumulation in lysosomes leads to the clinical features of this disease.
  • The disease usually presents with a triad of episodic peripheral neuropathy, angiokeratomas, and hypohidrosis in the early period.
  • In the late period of the disease, progressive renal failure and cardiovascular disease may lead to death.

Option D: Niemann-Pick disease

  • Niemann-Pick disease is a sphingomyelinase deficiency, resulting in progressive neurodegeneration and foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages).
  • Distinguishing features include hepatosplenomegaly and a "cherry-red" spot on the macula.

questions.text:
Match the following.


	
		
			
			Permanent social groups
			
			
			Definition
			
		
		
			
			a. Band
			
			
			1. Small collection of people permanently settled with cultural values.
			
		
		
			
			b. Town
			
			
			2. Most elementary community of a few families living together that have organized themselves and follow a pattern of life.
			
		
		
			
			c. Village
			
			
			3. Social group based on a defined geographical boundary, usually with a common culture, language, and code of conduct.
			
		
		
			
			d. State
			
			
			4. Permanent large, dense, urban settlements.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - a-2, b-4, c-1, d-3:

  • A band is defined as the most elementary community of a few families living together. Groups have organized themselves and follow a pattern of life.
  • A town is defined as a permanent large, dense, urban settlement.
  • A village is defined as a small collection of people permanently settled with cultural values.
  • State is defined as a social group based on a defined geographical boundary, usually with a common culture, language, and code of conduct.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are incorrect matches between the permanent social groups and their definition

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of hypertension. He reports experiencing occasional dizziness and headaches. His current medications include amlodipine 5 mg once daily. You decide to assess his blood pressure using home-based monitoring (HBPM). Which of the following statements regarding HBPM is correct?

choices.text: The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >140/90 mmHg
HBPM should be performed for 3 days, averaging both the morning and evening readings
The first-day value of HBPM should be discarded for accurate assessment
Cuff size should be 90% of arm circumference

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The first-day value of HBPM should be discarded for accurate assessment:

 The first-day value of HBPM should be discarded to eliminate potential measurement bias.

  • Home-based BP monitoring (HBPM) is recommended for tracking blood pressure (BP) outside of clinical settings.
  • Hypertension (HTN) is defined as BP consistently exceeding 135/85 mmHg at home.
  • HBPM involves measuring BP twice daily, in the morning and evening, for 7 days.
  • The first-day value is discarded, and the average of the remaining 6 days is calculated.
  • Proper cuff size is crucial, typically 80% of arm circumference, with width exceeding 40% of arm length.
  • Before measuring BP, individuals should rest for 5 minutes and wait 30 minutes after smoking or consuming coffee.
  • BP should be measured in both arms and legs to detect any discrepancies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >140/90 mmHg: The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >135/85 mmHg, not >140/90 mmHg.

Option B - The cutoff for hypertension using HBPM is >140/90 mmHg: HBPM should be performed for 7 days, both in the morning and evening, not for 3 days.

Option D -  Cuff size should be 90% of arm circumference: Cuff size should be 80% of arm circumference, not 90%.

questions.text: A neutropenic patient who recently underwent chemotherapy presents with fever, right lower quadrant tenderness, and bloody diarrhea. Imaging reveals a thickened cecal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis, and when is surgical intervention indicated?

choices.text: Typhlitis; indicated if no improvement within 24 hours of antibiotics
Crohn's disease; indicated if perforation leads to peritonitis
Ischemic colitis; indicated if imaging shows bowel necrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Typhlitis; indicated if no improvement within 24 hours of antibiotics:

  • The clinical presentation of fever, right lower quadrant tenderness, bloody diarrhea, and a thickened cecal wall on imaging is highly suggestive of typhlitis, also known as neutropenic colitis.
  • In typhlitis, medical management with antibiotics is the mainstay of treatment. Surgical intervention is warranted if there is no improvement within 24 hours of antibiotic therapy or if perforation occurs, which can lead to peritonitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diverticulitis; indicated if perforation occurs:

  • Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis typically presents with left lower quadrant pain and is not specifically associated with neutropenia or chemotherapy. Surgical intervention for diverticulitis is indicated if perforation occurs but is not solely based on the clinical scenario described.

Option C - Crohn's disease; indicated if perforation leads to peritonitis:

  • Crohn's disease: Crohn's disease presents with various symptoms including abdominal pain, diarrhea, and occasionally fever, but it is not specifically associated with neutropenia or chemotherapy. Surgical intervention in Crohn's disease is typically based on complications such as strictures or fistulas, rather than acute perforation.

Option D - Ischemic colitis; indicated if imaging shows bowel necrosis:

  • Ischemic colitis: Ischemic colitis presents with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea but is not specifically associated with neutropenia or chemotherapy. Surgical intervention in ischemic colitis may be indicated if there is evidence of bowel necrosis, but this is not mentioned in the clinical scenario provided.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of progressive muscle weakness and a characteristic skin rash as given below and proximal muscle weakness. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated muscle enzymes (creatine kinase) Which of the following findings would most likely be observed in the MRI-guided biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Perifascicular atrophy:

  • Perifascicular atrophy is a hallmark histopathological finding in dermatomyositis. It refers to the selective atrophy of muscle fibers at the periphery of muscle fascicles. This finding is highly indicative of dermatomyositis and correlates with clinical features such as muscle weakness and characteristic skin rashes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epidermal hyperplasia: Epidermal hyperplasia is a characteristic feature of psoriasis, not dermatomyositis.

Option C - Dermal fibrosis: Dermal fibrosis is more commonly associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) rather than dermatomyositis.

Option D - Eccrine gland hyperplasia: Eccrine gland hyperplasia is not a typical finding in dermatomyositis. It may be seen in conditions such as hyperhidrosis or certain inflammatory skin disorders.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male is scheduled for a nerve block procedure, and the anesthesia team is considering the use of adrenaline (epinephrine) to enhance the effects of the local anesthetic. In this context, in which of the following nerve blocks should the administration of adrenaline be avoided to prevent potential complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Penile nerve block:

  • The inclusion of adrenaline extends the duration of action of a local anesthetic by inducing vasoconstriction and reducing the absorption of the local anesthetic into the systemic circulation.
  • Adrenaline should be avoided in areas with end arterial supply, such as the penis, pinna, tip of the nose, and the distal parts of fingers and toes, as its use may lead to ischemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Brachial plexus block:

  • Adrenaline is commonly added to the local anesthetic in brachial plexus blocks. The vasoconstrictive effects of adrenaline help prolong the duration of anesthesia and reduce systemic absorption.

Option C - Epidural block:

  • Adrenaline is often included in epidural blocks. Its vasoconstrictive properties aid in reducing systemic absorption and enhancing the local anesthetic's efficacy.

Option D - Subarachnoid block:

  • Adrenaline is frequently used in subarachnoid (spinal) blocks. Similar to epidural blocks, it helps in vasoconstriction, extending the duration of the block and limiting systemic effects.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of facial plethora, neck swelling, and purplish discoloration across his chest. He is overweight with small-cell lung cancer (on treatment). On physical examination, a diffuse edema in the neck and dilated, engorged blood vessels on the chest (image) were noted. Except for mild dyspnea when supine and cough, the patient was asymptomatic and in no acute distress. Labs revealed a normal CBC and BMP. What is the probable clinical diagnosis from the given data?

choices.text: Congestive heart failure secondary to lung cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Superior vena cava syndrome:

  • In the above-given case, neck swelling, skin discoloration, obesity, edema, and dilated engorged blood vessels are suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulmonary hypertension:

  • It causes cyanosis, syncope, chest pain, palpitations, and shortness of breath.

Option B - Congestive heart failure secondary to lung cancer:

  • Congestive heart failure causes shortness of breath, pedal edema, palpitations, and persistent cough.

Option D - Paraneoplastic syndrome of SCLC:

  • SIADH causes increased peripheral pain, muscular pain, dementia, difficulty in swallowing, slurred speech, loss of motor coordination, and seizures.

questions.text: What is the grade of DAI seen in this case as per Adam’s grading:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Grade 1:

  • The image shows diffuse axonal injury grade 1 as Gray matter and white matter interface are involved.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Grade 3:

  • Grade 3 shows brainstem involvement, which is not seen in this case.

Option C - Grade 4:

  • There is no grade 4 in Adam’s grading.

Option D - Grade 2:

  • Grade 2 shows corpus callosum involvement, which is not seen in the given image.

questions.text:
Arrange the following gluconeogenesis enzymes in the correct sequence:


	Pyruvate carboxylase
	Glucose-6-phosphatase
	Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase
	Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1→3→4→2:

  • All enzymes given in the question are used to bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis.
  • Enzymes of gluconeogenesis that bypass the irreversible reactions of glycolysis act in the following sequence:
  • Pyruvate carboxylase: converts pyruvate to OAA (in mitochondria).
  • Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: converts OAA to phosphoenolpyruvate.
  • Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase: cleaves fructose 1,6 bisphosphate to fructose 6-P.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase performs the last step of releasing free glucose from glucose 6-P (in ER).

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of option B.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male is admitted to the ward. He is a chronic alcoholic and has been diagnosed with liver cirrhosis. He is scheduled for the removal of the segments with blue shades. What is the name of this procedure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Left trisectionectomy

  • The resection of three segments (typically of the liver) is trisectionectomy.
  • Left trisectionectomy, also known as an extended left hepatectomy, involves the removal of the Couinaud’s Segments 2,3,4,5 and 8.
  • Segments 2, 3, 4, 5, and 8 are removed in the illustration; hence the treatment is known as a left trisectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy.

 

  • The falciform ligament splits the left lateral segment from the left medial segment rather than separating the right and left lobes.

 

Option A: Left hepatectomy

  • It involves the removal of the Couinaud’s Segments labeled as 2,3,4 in the image above.

Option C: Right trisectionectomy

  • Right trisectionectomy involves the removal of the Couinaud’s Segments 4,5,6,7 and 8.

Option D: Extended right hepatectomy

  • Extended right hepatectomy is the other name for right trisectionectomy.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			Drugs

Correct Option C - 1d,2c,3a,4b:

      • Inhibits the release of inflammatory mediators

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male complains of blurred vision and photophobia in both eyes for the past month. He also reports experiencing hair loss and patchy depigmentation of the skin. An ophthalmic examination reveals bilateral panuveitis, and a fundus examination shows the findings in the image below. What is this finding known as and in which condition it is seen?

choices.text: Suguira’s sign, seen in VKH Syndrome
Sunset fundus, seen in VKH syndrome
Suguira’s sign seen in Sympathetic Ophthalmitis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sunset fundus, seen in VKH syndrome 

  • The clinical picture in the question gives the diagnosis of VKH syndrome, and the finding seen in the image is the Sunset fundus, which is seen in phase III (Convalescent phase) of VKH Syndrome. Sunset fundus is due to choroidal depigmentation.

    • Phase I: The prodromal phase Presents with neurological and auditory manifestations.
    • Phase II: Acute uveitis phase. Presents with granulomatous pan uveitis. In posterior uveitis later leads to exudative retinal detachment
    • Phase III: Convalescent phase. Perilimbal depigmentation, aka Suguira's sign. Choroidal depigmentation, aka sunset fundus
    • Phase IV: Chronic recurrent phase It manifests as anterior uveitis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Suguira’s sign, seen in VKH Syndrome: Suguira’s sign is Perilimbal depigmentation seen in VKH syndrome.

Option C - Suguira’s sign seen in Sympathetic Ophthalmitis: Suguira’s sign is Perilimbal depigmentation seen in VKH syndrome, not in Sympathetic Ophthalmitis.

Option D - None of the above: Sunset fundus is seen in VKH syndrome.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with a travel history to Southeast Asia presents with fever, cough, and skin lesions after encountering bamboo rats. Papules on the face, chest, and extremities are observed on examination. Microscopic analysis of skin lesion samples shows fungi with brush-like conidia on conidiophores. Which fungal species is most likely responsible for the skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Talaromyces marneffei:

  • Talaromyces marneffei (penicillium marneffei a dimorphic fungi) is associated with infections in individuals who come into contact with bamboo rats, which serve as a natural reservoir for the fungus. The presence of brush-like conidia on conidiophores is a unique feature of Talaromyces marneffei. 
  • Most patients with talaromycosis present with signs and symptoms related to infection of the reticuloendothelial system, including generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly. Skin lesions are seen in approximately 70 percent of patients, and when present, they are the best clue to diagnosis. Patients may also present with respiratory, gastrointestinal, and neurologic findings.

Incorrect Options-

Option A - Candida albicans: Candida albicans is a yeast known to cause various fungal infections, including oral thrush and vaginal yeast infections. .

Option B - Aspergillus fumigatus: Aspergillus fumigatus is a mold that can cause a range of respiratory infections, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis and invasive aspergillosis. Additionally, the skin lesions progressing into ulcers do not align with the common presentations of Aspergillus infections.

Option D - Trichophyton rubrum: Trichophyton rubrum is a dermatophyte fungus that can cause various skin infections, including athlete's foot, and onychomycsis.

questions.text: A study conducted in a rural community recorded the number of cases of a particular infectious disease over the course of ten days. The data set contains the following observations: 4, 1, 2, 4, 4, 1, 2, 3. Which of the following is the mode of this data?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - 4:

  • The mode of this data is 4 as it appears three times in the given data set.
  • It is the most repeated or frequently occurring value in a data set.
  • The mode is least affected by outliers (extreme values).

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, C:

  • These are not the mode values of the given data.

questions.text: The given image is associated with which type of multiple endocrine neoplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2B:

  • Mucosal neuromas are characterized by the presence of bumpy lips and tongue. These growths develop on the mucous membranes, which line various parts of the body, including the lips and tongue.
  • Mucosal neuromas are typically associated with conditions such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN2B), a rare genetic disorder.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect due to the above given reason.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female arrives at the emergency department with her friend. She slipped and fell down a flight of stairs, hitting her head on the ground. Which of the following vessels will most likely be injured due to trauma on the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Middle meningeal artery:

  • The marked area in the image is Pterion.
  • It is the 'H' shaped point where frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones meet.
  • The anterior division of the middle meningeal artery lies under this point and is vulnerable to damage due to trauma leading to extradural hemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Internal carotid artery:

  • The internal carotid artery is one of the main arterial supplies of the brain. It does not lie beneath the Pterion and is not damaged due to trauma at this point.

Option C - Anterior cerebral artery:

  • Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery supplying the anterior cerebrum. It does not lie beneath the Pterion.

Option D - Deep temporal artery:

  • The deep temporal arteries (anterior, middle and posterior) are the branches of the second part of the maxillary artery.
  • This artery is damaged due to traumatic injury of the zygomatic arch, not the Pterion.

questions.text: The "Feluda Test," developed by Indian scientists, employs a novel detection approach based on a renowned genome editing technology. What is the underlying principle of this test?

choices.text: Utilizing Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) for target amplification
Relying on enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for protein detection
Leveraging gas chromatography for chemical analysis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Employing CRISPR-Cas9 for genome editing:

  • The "Feluda Test" utilizes CRISPR-Cas9 (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats-Cas9) technology, which is typically known for genome editing. In this context, it's being applied to detect specific genetic material. The distinctive features that contribute to its rapidity and efficiency include the use of a paper-based test strip, allowing for simple visualization of results. The entire process takes less than 45 minutes, making it a quick and efficient method for detecting the target genetic material.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Utilizing Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) for target amplification: PCR is a technique used to amplify a specific DNA sequence.

Option B- Relying on enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for protein detection: ELISA is a method used to detect the presence of specific proteins using antibodies.

Option D- Leveraging gas chromatography for chemical analysis: Gas chromatography is a technique used for separating and analysing complex mixtures, primarily for chemical analysis.

questions.text: What is the cause of earache in a patient with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing, and what are the given examination findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Irritation of glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • The given clinical findings are suggestive of acute tonsilitis. The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) innervates the tonsillar bed and gives rise to a plexus known as the tympanic plexus, extending into the middle ear. Irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve due to tonsillitis can lead to referred otalgia or ear pain.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Middle ear infections:

  • In this case of acute tonsilitis, the cause of earache is referred otalgia by the glossopharyngeal nerve, not middle ear infections.

Option B - Irritation of vagus nerve:

  • In this case of acute tonsilitis, the cause of earache is referred otalgia by the glossopharyngeal nerve, not by the vagus nerve.

Option D - Eustachian tube blockage:

  • In this case of acute tonsilitis, the cause of earache is referred otalgia by the glossopharyngeal nerve, not Eustachian tube dysfunction.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nulliparous woman is undergoing evaluation for infertility. She is being monitored for ovulation with serial ultrasounds and LH levels. Ovulation is expected after how many hours of the ‘Peak’ of the ‘Upstroke’ in this diagram here:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: 10-12 hours

  • From the onset of the LH surge, it takes 24-36 hours and from the peak, it takes 10-12 hours to ovulate.
  • The midcycle LH surge is responsible for a dramatic increase in local concentrations of prostaglandins and proteolytic enzymes in the follicle. These substances progressively weaken the follicular wall and ultimately allow a perforation to form.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 0-6 hours

Option C: 12-24 hours

Option D: 24-36 hours

questions.text: A patient presented with frontal scalp and periorbital swelling, fever, purulent rhinorrhoea, photophobia, frontal sinus tenderness, and vomiting. On examination, signs of meningitis and encephalitis were present. Which sinus among the following is affected in Pott’s puffy tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Abscess of frontal sinus:

  • Subdural empyema associated with osteomyelitis of the frontal bone and associated scalp swelling, which pits on pressure, is Pott's puffy tumor. Since Pott's puffy tumor involves osteomyelitis of the frontal bone, an underlying abscess of the frontal sinus may be associated.

Pott’s puffy tumor:

  • Pott’s puffy tumor is one of the most dangerous complications of frontal sinusitis and is characterized by osteomyelitis of the frontal bone with an associated subperiosteal abscess.
  • Symptoms include frontal scalp and periorbital swelling, fever, purulent rhinorrhoea, photophobia, frontal sinus tenderness, vomiting, and signs of meningitis or encephalitis.
  • Pott’s Puffy Tumor can lead to life-threatening complications.
  • In 85% of patients, Pott’s puffy tumor is a predictor of intracranial complications such as meningitis, cavernous sinus and dural venous sinus thrombosis, orbital cellulitis with or without intraorbital abscess (if the inferior wall of the frontal sinus is involved) and epidural, subdural or intraparenchymal abscesses.
  • The spread of the infection can occur either due to direct extension by erosion of frontal sinus walls or by migration of septic thrombi through the diploic veins.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Abscess of maxillary sinus:

  • Pott's puffy tumor involves osteomyelitis of the frontal bone. An underlying abscess of the frontal sinus may be associated.
  • There are two large maxillary sinuses, one in each of the maxillary bones, in the cheek area next to the nose. The maxillary sinuses are lined with cells that make mucus to keep the nose from drying out.
  • The clinical features of the question are not suggestive of maxillary sinus abscess.

Option C - Abscess of the ethmoid sinus:

  • Pott’s puffy tumor involves osteomyelitis of the frontal bone, and an underlying abscess of the frontal sinus may be associated.
  • The ethmoid sinuses are hollow spaces in the bones around the nose. They have a lining of mucus to help prevent the nose from drying out. Inflammation of the ethmoid sinuses can lead to pressure and pain around the nose and between the eyes.
  • The clinical features of the question are not suggestive of ethmoid sinus abscess.

Option D - Abscess of the sphenoid sinus:

  • Pott’s puffy tumor involves osteomyelitis of the frontal bone, and an underlying abscess of the frontal sinus may be associated.
  • Sphenoid sinus: Paranasal sinus (a hollow space in the bones around the nose). Two large sphenoid sinuses are in the sphenoid bone, which is behind the nose between the eyes. The sphenoid sinuses are lined with cells that make mucus to keep the nose from drying out.
  • The clinical features of the question are not suggestive of sphenoid sinus abscess.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic patient with a history of limited jaw movement and severe otalgia. On examination, granulation tissue is seen in the external auditory canal. What is the likely causative agent responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • The above given scenario is suggestive of Malignant Otitis Externa (MOE):
  • Caused by Pseudomonas infection, often in immunosuppressed patients.
  • Characterized by severe and excruciating ear pain.
  • Infection may spread anteriorly to the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), causing pain and limited movement.
  • High risk of spread due to compromised immunity.
  • Requires prompt medical attention and aggressive treatment to prevent complications and systemic spread.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A -  Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus is not the typical causative agent for Necrotizing Otitis Media.

Option C - Group A β-hemolytic streptococcus:

  • NSOM is specifically associated with Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus.

Option D - Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is not the primary causative agent for Necrotizing Otitis Media.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Screening
			
			
			Gestational Age
			
		
		
			
			a. Anomaly scan
			
			
			1)16 weeks
			
		
		
			
			b. NT scan
			
			
			2)12 weeks
			
		
		
			
			c. Triple marker test
			
			
			3) 22 weeks
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - a-3,b-2,c-1:

  • Anomaly scan is done between 18-24 weeks
  • NT scan is done at 12 weeks
  • A triple marker test is done at 16 weeks

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D:

  • These do not indicate the correct match between the screening tests and the gestational age at which they are done

questions.text: A 28-year-old female comes to gynecology OPD for counseling. She missed a dose of combined OCPs and is anxious about the possibility of conceiving. Her menstrual cycle is regular and she is sexually active with her boyfriend. She had unprotected intercourse a day back. What should be the future course of action?

choices.text: She can take the missed pill as soon as possible.
She can continue her regular schedule without any changes
She should switch to a barrier contraceptive method.
She should take emergency contraceptive pills.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- She can take the missed pill as soon as possible:

  • If a woman on combined oral contraceptives (OCPs) misses one pill, she can take the missed pill as soon as possible and then resume her regular schedule. There is no significant risk of pregnancy with one missed pill, especially if it is promptly taken.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - She can continue her regular schedule without any changes:

  • Continuing the regular schedule without addressing the missed pill could increase the risk of pregnancy, so it's essential to take the missed pill as soon as possible.

Option C- She should switch to a barrier contraceptive method:

  • Switching to a barrier contraceptive method is recommended if three or more pills are missed, not for just one missed pill.

Option D - She should take emergency contraceptive pills:

  • This is not needed as with one missed pill, no risk of pregnancy is there.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in the decreased sensation, burning, and pins and needles sensation in the right arm's ring and little finger of the 42-year-old cyclist?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Ulnar nerve

Guyon canal syndrome:

  • The case given in the question stem is Guyon canal syndrome.
  • This syndrome results due to peripheral ulnar neuropathy.
  • The neuropathy can be due to an injury involving the distal portion of the ulnar nerve.
  • The nerve root value of the ulnar nerve is C8-T1, a terminal branch of the brachial plexus.
  • The patient presents with weakness and sensory loss of the medial side of the hand involving the ring and little finger.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Radial nerve

  • The nerve compression at the axilla is due to crutches or sleeping with an arm The radial nerve palsy is caused by nerve compression at the axilla due to crutches or sleeping with an arm over the chair (Saturday night palsy); at the midshaft fracture of humerus repetitive pronation/supination of the forearm, e.g., due to screwdriver use (finger drop) or Injuries above the elbow cause loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand, wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extensions) with grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors).

Option B: Median nerve

  • Median nerve palsy is caused by Supracondylar fracture of the humerus due to a proximal nerve lesion; Carpal tunnel syndrome and wrist laceration cause distal nerve lesion.

Option C: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • It is caused by upper trunk compression, which causes decreased biceps reflex, and loss of forearm flexion and supination; also, loss of sensation occurs over the radial and dorsal forearm.

questions.text: Which structure listed below is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Option D: Neurohypophysis

  • The ectoderm is the outermost layer of the three germ layers.
  • During neurulation, ectoderm differentiates into surface ectoderm and neural ectoderm.
  • The surface ectoderm forms the organs and structures which maintain contact with the outside world.
  • The neuroectoderm forms:
    • The central nervous system
    • The peripheral nervous system
  • Surface ectoderm is responsible for forming:
    • The epidermis of the skin, including hair and nails
    • The mammary glands
    • The sweat glands
    • The sebaceous glands
    • The sensory epithelium of the ear, nose, and eye
    • Enamel of teeth
    • Internal ear
    • The anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
  • Neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary) comes from the neural plate ectoderm.

Option A: Sweat gland

  • Sweat glands are derived from surface ectoderm.
  • Both eccrine and apocrine sweat glands are the derivatives of surface ectoderm.
  • The development of sweat glands begins at 12-13 weeks and is completed at around 22 weeks post-fertilization.

Option B: Oral opening

  • The oral opening is formed from the surface ectoderm.
  • Stomodeum, also known as primitive mouth, is a depression in the ectoderm and develops into the mouth and oral cavity.
  • The oral opening is lined by epithelial cells, which are derivatives of surface ectoderm.
  • The craniofacial skeleton is formed by the neural crest cells, which is also a derivative of ectoderm.

Option C: Rathke's pouch

  • Rathke’s pouch is a derivative of ectoderm.
  • An evagination at the roof-developing mouth is called Rathke’s pouch.
  • Rathke’s pouch is an outpouching of the stomodeum. It gives rise to the anterior pituitary gland.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1L1 at 34 weeks of pregnancy presents with high-grade fever with chills and rigor. Her CBC shows Hb 8.8 gm%, TLC 10,500 platelet count 1.8 lakhs, malarial parasite slide positive for plasmodium vivax, and liver and renal functions are normal. USG shows a single live fetus with normal parameters and liquor. Which is the most appropriate first-line pharmacological therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Chloroquine

  • Chloroquine is considered safe for use in pregnancy and is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated Plasmodium vivax malaria in pregnant women.
  • It is effective against the asexual erythrocytic forms of the parasite.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Mefloquine

  • Mefloquine is generally avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy due to potential concerns. However, it may be considered in the second and third trimesters if other options are unavailable or ineffective.
  • Its safety in pregnancy is not well-established, and it is not considered a first-line option.

Option C: Artesunate

  • Artesunate is effective against severe malaria and is generally considered safe in the second and third trimesters of pregnancy.
  • It is recommended for severe malaria, but for uncomplicated cases, other options like chloroquine are preferred.

Option D: Lumefantrine

  • It is used in pregnancy to treat malaria for complicated cases requiring ACT (Artemisinin Combination Therapy).
  • Limited data available regarding the safety profile of artemisinins in early pregnancy.
  • They are, therefore, not recommended by WHO as the first-line treatment for malaria in the first trimester due to associated embryo-fetal toxicity in animal studies.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common organism associated with Fournier’s gangrene in a known diabetic and hypertensive patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Streptococcus:

  • Fournier's gangrene is necrotizing fascitis of the genitalia, usually affecting the scrotum and penis.
  • Many types of bacteriological cultures, both single strain and polymicrobial cultures, have been encountered in Fournier's gangrene.
  • The most common causative organism is Streptococcus pyogenes (Beta-hemolytic streptococci).
  • Others are Staphylococcus aureus, Enterobacteriaceae (E. coli, Klebsiella, proteus), Enterococci, Pseudomonas, and Anaerobes like Bacteroides and Peptostreptococcus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Staphylococcus:

  • Staphylococcus aureus has been identified as the most common cause of pyomyositis.
  • Pyomyositis is a localized infection of skeletal muscles.

Option C - Proteus:

  • Proteus is pleomorphic bacillus → Any shape , Gram-negative-capsulated, Fishy odour, Swarming growth is seen.
  • It does not lead to Fournier's gangrene.

Option D - Pneumococcus:

  • Necrotizing fascitis due to streptococcus pneumonia is very rare.
  • It is one of the main causes of community-acquired pneumonia and meningitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Brighton Criteria used for Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)?

choices.text: Normal CSF cell count and elevated protein

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Biphasic course:

  • GBS typically follows a monophasic course, meaning it occurs as a single episode that lasts from 12 hours to 28 days.

Brighton Criteria:

  • Flaccid Bilateral weakness of limbs
  • Areflexia in weakness
  • CytoAlbuminologic dissociation
  • Monophasic illness: 12 hrs - 28 days
  • EDx findings of demyelination

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are components of Brighton Criteria for Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

questions.text: What is the main advantage of the DIEP flap over the TRAM flap in breast reconstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lower risk of hernia:

  • The main advantage of the DIEP (Deep Inferior Epigastric Artery Perforator) flap over the TRAM (Transverse Rectus Abdominis Muscle) flap in breast reconstruction is the lower risk of hernia. In the TRAM flap procedure, a portion of the rectus abdominis muscle is often used, which can weaken the abdominal wall and increase the risk of developing a hernia postoperatively. However, in the DIEP flap procedure, the muscle is spared, reducing this risk significantly.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not advantages of the DIEP flap over the TRAM flap.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is performed, showing the findings given below.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoid macular edema :

  • The OCT examination in the above patient shows presence of cystoid spaces filled with fluid . These findings along with the presenting clinical features indicate the presence of cystoid macular edema.

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) is swelling of the layers of the neurosensory retina within the macula. When excess fluid builds in the retina, it typically collects in “pockets,” referred to as “cysts.”

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Slow, painless loss of vision
  • Metamorphopsia (distortion of shape)
  • Micropsia (objects appear small and distorted) or macropsia (objects appear large and distorted)

Diagnostic Tools:

  • Amsler's grid
  • +90 D lens (best instrument to examine CME)

Investigations:

Fluorescein Angiography (FA):

  • Dye used: Fluorescein Sodium
  • Arm retina circulation time: 12 seconds
  • Pattern of leak indicates pathology
  • Limitations: invasive and may cause allergy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • Gold standard investigation for all macular disorders
  • Non-invasive
  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the retina

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central serous retinopathy: It typically presents with serous retinal detachment and fluid accumulation underneath the neurosensory retina, often occurring in younger patients and often associated with stress or corticosteroid use.

Option C - Retinal detachment : It involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium and is associated with symptoms like flashes of light and a sensation of a "curtain" coming down over the vision.

Option D - Age related macular degeneration : It is characterized by the gradual deterioration of the macula, often leading to central vision loss, but it usually presents with drusen and pigmentary changes, rather than cystic spaces seen in CME.

Match the following:

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to recent development of vomiting, gagging, trouble swallowing, and inability to walk properly. His hand-eye coordination has been progressively worsening. An MRI showed the cerebellum herniating into the foramen magnum. Which of the following signs would be elicited by an ocular examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Downbeat nystagmus:

  • Downbeat nystagmus is a type of involuntary eye movement characterized by the eyes drifting upward and then rapidly moving downward. It is often associated with abnormalities in the cerebellum and brainstem, which are affected in Arnold-Chiari malformation. The compression of the brainstem can disrupt the neural pathways responsible for controlling eye movements, leading to the characteristic downward drift of the eyes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seesaw nystagmus:

  • Seesaw nystagmus is a type of nystagmus characterized by a rhythmic, reciprocal, up-and-down movement of the eyes. It is often associated with lesions in the area of the optic chiasma.

Option B - Bruns nystagmus:

  • Bruns nystagmus is characterized by horizontal nystagmus that changes direction, often associated with lesions affecting the midbrain (cerebellopontine angle). The symptoms described in the case, along with cerebellar herniation, are more suggestive of involvement in the posterior fossa (cerebellum and brainstem), making Bruns nystagmus less likely.

Option C - Convergence retraction nystagmus:

  • Convergence retraction nystagmus is a specific type of nystagmus associated with lesions in the midbrain, such as the dorsal midbrain syndrome (Parinaud syndrome). While midbrain involvement is possible in Arnold-Chiari malformation, convergence retraction nystagmus is not a typical finding in this context.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female, primigravida, presents to a gynecological ER with a history of PV spotting and gradual onset dull right-sided flank pain associated with nausea and vomiting. The transvaginal ultrasound scan shows no gestational sac in the uterine cavity. Spot serum β-hCG levels are 410 mIU/ml, whereas the levels were 880 mIU/ml 3 weeks ago. Laparoscopy reveals 125ml of blood in the pelvis and a freely floating placental tissue in the peritoneal cavity. What is the most likely condition she has suffered from?
questions.solution:
Correct option B:

  • A tubal abortion may present in this manner, with floating placental and fetal tissues in free peritoneal blood.
  • The most common termination of an ectopic is that the pregnancy outgrows the blood supply of the tube and eventual vascular insufficiency causes degeneration. Rupture of the tube is a rare outcome.

Fate of ectopic

  • Most common: vascular insufficiency at the ectopic site, drop in β-hCG (drop in progesterone) withdrawal bleeding from the uterus due to shedding of the decidua.
  • Tubal abortion: second most common
  • Rupture of tube: rarest occurrence.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: A spontaneous abortion presents as the passage of tissues vaginally, in case of an intrauterine pregnancy.

Option C: Decidual cast is the sloughing of the endometrial decidual reaction all at one go instead of a few days on menstrual shedding. It presents as passage of a tissue and is associated with severe dysmenorrhea.

Option D: The Arias-Stella phenomenon is a benign change in the endometrium secondary to the progesterone effect, associated with the presence of a pregnancy, often not in the uterus.

questions.text: A 48-year-old menopausal woman presents with perineal itching. On examination, there is mild vulvar atrophy. A biopsy taken from the site is negative for malignancy.  Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Topical Estrogen

  • Vulvar atrophy is often a result of decreased estrogen levels during menopause, leading to thinning and drying of the vaginal and vulvar tissues. Topical estrogen, in the form of a cream or ointment, can help alleviate symptoms by restoring the local estrogen levels and improving the health of the vulvar tissues. This is a common and effective treatment for menopausal symptoms like perineal itching.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Antihistamines

  • Antihistamines would relieve itching temporarily, but they do not address the underlying cause of vulvar atrophy, which is estrogen deficiency during menopause. Therefore, antihistamines may not be the most appropriate primary treatment.

Option C: Tamoxifen

  • Tamoxifen is a medication commonly used in the treatment of breast cancer. It is not indicated for managing perineal itching or vulvar atrophy. Tamoxifen may be associated with an increased risk of vaginal dryness and discomfort, which is the opposite of what is needed in this case.

Option D: Oral antifungal treatment

  • Oral antifungal drugs treat fungal infections, most common on skin, nails and hair.
  • These are used to treat dermatophytosis and chronic yeast infections.
  • It is not used here because the patient likely has menopausal changes.

questions.text: Which imaging modality is most suitable for assessing complications post-cochlear implant surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- High-Resolution Computed Tomography (HRCT):

  • High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) is the most suitable imaging modality for assessing complications post-cochlear implant surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- X-ray:

  • X-rays are used to assess the position of the implant.

Option C- Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI):

  • MRI is not the most suitable imaging modality for assessing complications.

Option D- Ultrasonography:

  • Ultrasonography is not commonly used for assessing complications.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			Dwarf megakaryocyte
			
			
			A.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			Staghorn megakaryocyte
			
			
			B.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			Pawn ball megakaryocyte
			
			
			C.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			Cloud-like megakaryocyte
			
			
			D.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B:

  • (1) Dwarf megakaryocyte is matched with image C which shows the small megakaryocyte size. It is commonly seen in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML).

  • (2) Staghorn megakaryocyte is matched with image A as it exhibits a nucleus shaped like a deer horn. It is observed in Essential Thrombocythemia (ET).

  • (3) Pawn ball megakaryocyte is matched with image D as there are three nuclei present resembling a pawn ball. It is characteristic of Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS).

  • (4) Cloud-like megakaryocyte is matched with image B as shows a nucleus in the megakaryocyte resembling a cloud, and it is commonly seen in Myelofibrosis.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with tearing, photophobia, and tight closure of the eyelid in the right eye. Upon examination, increased intraocular pressure, buphthalmos, and the following findings were observed in the right eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Congenital Glaucoma:

  • In this scenario, the presence of tearing, photophobia, blepharospasm and buphthalmos, along with the finding of Haab's striae (in the given image) which are horizontal breaks in Descemet's membrane, strongly suggests congenital glaucoma. Congenital glaucoma is characterized by elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) due to abnormalities in the development of the eye's drainage system (trabecular meshwork). It typically presents in early infancy and can lead to corneal clouding, enlargement of the globe (buphthalmos), and other signs of increased IOP.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumor of the retina that primarily affects young children. While it can present with symptoms such as leukocoria (white pupillary reflex), strabismus, and vision loss, it is not typically associated with tearing, photophobia, or enlargement of the globe. Additionally, the absence of other characteristic findings of retinoblastoma, such as intraocular mass or retinal detachment, makes this an unlikely diagnosis in the given scenario.

Option B - Amblyopia:

  • Amblyopia, commonly known as "lazy eye," is a condition characterized by reduced visual acuity in one eye that is not correctable by glasses or contact lenses. It typically results from abnormal visual development during childhood. While tearing and photophobia are not typically associated with amblyopia, the most distinguishing feature is the significant difference in visual acuity between the affected eye and the normal eye. In the given scenario, the absence of visual acuity disparity between the eyes makes amblyopia an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D - Keratoconus:

  • Keratoconus is a progressive thinning and bulging of the cornea, resulting in a conical shape. It usually manifests during adolescence or early adulthood and is characterized by blurry vision, astigmatism, and corneal irregularities. While photophobia can occur in keratoconus due to irregular astigmatism, tearing and enlargement of the globe are not typical features of the condition. Additionally, the absence of corneal irregularities and the presence of Haab's striae suggest a different diagnosis in the given scenario.

questions.text: In a rural area, a program has been initiated to train birth attendants to improve maternal and neonatal health outcomes. As part of the training criteria, a set of requirements are established. Which of the following statements about the trained birth attendants in rural areas is FALSE?

choices.text: One trained birth attendant for every 1000 population
Completion of a one-month training program
Conducting a minimum of two supervised deliveries during the training period

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - At least 6th pass:

  • An extensive program has been undertaken under the Rural Health Scheme to train all categories of local dais (traditional birth attendants).
  • The emphasis during training is on asepsis so that home deliveries are conducted safely in hygienic conditions reducing maternal and neonatal mortality.
  • After successfully completing training, a certificate is provided along with a delivery kit.
  • No educational qualifications are required to acquire this training.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - One trained birth attendant for every 1000 population:

  • It indicates the recommended ratio of trained birth attendants to the population, ensuring adequate coverage for maternal and neonatal care in rural areas.
  • These birth attendants are expected to play a vital role in propagating small family norms since they are more acceptable to the community.

Option C - Completion of a one-month training program:

  • It outlines the duration of the training program required for individuals to become trained birth attendants, providing them with the necessary knowledge and skills to assist in childbirth safely.
  • Training is given at the PHC, or Sub-center for 2 days a week, and on the remaining 4 days of the week, they accompany the HWF to the villages.

Option D - Conducting a minimum of two supervised deliveries during the training period:

  • The minimum number of supervised deliveries required during training is two.
  • Conducting a higher number of supervised deliveries ensures that birth attendants gain sufficient practical experience and competency in managing childbirth complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with generalized weakness and other neurological complaints. Upon further inquiry, you discover that he consumes large quantities of a particular legume (shown below) as a staple in his diet. On examination, you notice exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is a clinical feature of this condition?

choices.text: Spastic paralysis of the lower limb
Spastic paralysis of the upper limb
Flaccid paralysis of the upper limb
Flaccid paralysis of the lower limb

questions.solution:
Correct option A - Spastic paralysis of the lower limb:

  • Neurolathyrism is a neurological disorder caused by the consumption of the legume Lathyrus sativus (khesari dal).

  • Clinical features:

    • Spastic paralysis of the lower limb.
    • Stages of Spastic Paralysis of Lower Limb
      • Latent stage
      • One stick stage
      • Two-stick stage
  • It is a consequence of food adulteration (any substance added to a food product that decreases the nutritive value and harms the body).
  • The toxin present is Beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA).
  • This disorder primarily affects the lower limbs, resulting in spastic paralysis characterized by increased tone, exaggerated reflexes, and weakness in the lower limbs.
  • The condition typically manifests as a stiff-legged gait due to spasticity in the lower extremities.
  • Interventions include:
    • Vitamin C prophylaxis (500 to 1000 mg in a week)
    • Toxin removal by steeping and parboiling
    • Health education
    • Banning the crop
    • Genetic approach

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Spastic paralysis of the upper limb:

  • Neurolathyrism primarily affects the lower limbs rather than the upper limbs.
  • While spasticity may occur in severe cases, it is more commonly observed in the lower limbs.
  • Therefore, spastic paralysis of the upper limb is not a characteristic feature of neurolathyrism.

Option C - Flaccid paralysis of the upper limb:

  • Flaccid paralysis refers to a condition characterized by weakness and decreased muscle tone.
  • Neurolathyrism does not typically present with flaccid paralysis, as it primarily affects the upper motor neurons, leading to spasticity rather than flaccidity.
  • Therefore, flaccid paralysis of the upper limb is an incorrect clinical feature for neurolathyrism.

Option D: Flaccid paralysis of the lower limb:

  • Similarly, neurolathyrism does not typically manifest as flaccid paralysis in the lower limbs.
  • Flaccid paralysis is more indicative of lower motor neuron lesions rather than upper motor neuron dysfunction, which is characteristic of neurolathyrism.
  • Therefore, flaccid paralysis of the lower limb is not a clinical feature of neurolathyrism.

questions.text: Observe the image below and determine the group of the sample used:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A+:

  • The test depicted in the given image is a Gel Card test for blood grouping.

 

The principle involved is:

  • After mixing the patient's blood sample with specific antibodies against blood group antigens, the red blood cells (RBCs) agglutinate if they react with the corresponding antibodies. Agglutinated RBCs cannot pass through the gel due to their size; so they accumulate at the top of the gel column, forming a visible line. This line indicates a positive reaction, suggesting the presence of the specific blood group antigen on the patient's RBCs.  
  • Conversely, if the patient's RBCs do not react with the antibodies and remain unagglutinated, they can freely pass through the gel and settle at the bottom of the gel column during centrifugation. This results in the formation of a visible line at the bottom of the gel card, indicating a negative reaction, which suggests the absence of the specific blood group antigen on the patient's RBCs.
  • GIVEN THIS : the sample used in the test shown is A+

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient is brought to the clinic complaining of a large erythematous skin pocket on his sacrum and left hip. He has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus, paraplegia, and steroid-induced diabetes, diagnosed two years ago. Examination reveals large 3-4 cm pressure sores, as shown in the image below. Which would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Surgery is the only modality of the treatment
A fasciocutaneous flap should be used
Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies.
Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Stage 2 and 3 ulcers may be left to heal secondarily after debridement:

  • Stage 2 and 3 pressure ulcers, as seen in the image, typically involve partial thickness skin loss or full thickness tissue loss, respectively.
  • Treatment often involves debridement to remove necrotic tissue and promote healing.
  • Leaving the ulcers to heal secondarily after debridement allows for natural wound healing processes to occur without the need for surgical intervention.
  • This approach is suitable, particularly considering the patient's comorbidities such as systemic lupus erythematosus, paraplegia, and steroid-induced diabetes, which may increase surgical risks.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Surgery is the only modality of treatment:

  • While surgery may be necessary in some cases of pressure ulcers, it is not the only treatment modality, especially for stage 2 and 3 ulcers.
  • Non-surgical interventions such as debridement and wound care are often utilized.

Option B - A fasciocutaneous flap should be used:

  • While flap surgery may be considered in severe cases of pressure ulcers, it is not always the most appropriate initial treatment, especially for stage 2 and 3 ulcers.
  • Flap surgery is typically reserved for more advanced or non-responsive cases.

Option C - Herbal remedies with or without insulin are mostly useful than other remedies:

  • Herbal remedies and insulin are not the primary treatments for pressure ulcers.
  • Wound care, debridement, and addressing underlying factors such as pressure relief are essential in managing pressure ulcers.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician with complaints of a fever. His examination reveals a murmur and a generalised rash on the patient’s body, as shown below.



The skin condition shown in the picture is associated with which of the following heart conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rheumatic Heart Disease

  • The skin rash shown in the picture is erythema marginatum. It is a feature of rheumatic heart disease.
  • It occurs due to molecular mimicry. 
  • The M protein of pneumococcal is almost identical to cardiomyocytes. 
  • As a result, the antibodies formed in response to strep infection can attack the cardiomyocytes leading to rheumatic heart disease.
  • Modified Jones criteria (for moderate-high risk population such as in India):
    • Major criteria
      • Carditis (clinical or subclinical) 
      • Arthritis (polyarthritis, polyarthralgia, and/or monoarthritis)
      • Chorea 
      • Erythema marginatum
      • Subcutaneous nodule
    • Minor criteria
      • Polyarthralgia
      • Fever (≥38.0 °C)
      • Elevation of ESR (≥30 mm in the 1st hour) and/or CRP ≥3 mg/dL
      • Prolonged PR interval, corrected for age (only when there is no carditis)
  • RHD is diagnosed when:
    • Initial episode of RF: 2 major or 1 major with 2 minor criteria
    • Recurrence of RF: 2 major or 1 major with 2 minor or 3 minor

Option A: Eisenmenger’s Syndrome

  • In Eisenmenger’s syndrome, there is increased pressure on the right heart due to pulmonary hypertension or a left-to-right shunt in a congenital heart defect. The right heart pressure can exceed the left heart pressure causing cyanosis and polycythemia.
  • It usually occurs in advanced cases of septal defects in congenital heart diseases.
  • The skin manifestations of Eisenmenger’s syndrome are clubbing and cyanosis, not erythema marginatum. Hence, this condition is less likely.

Option C: Infective Endocarditis

  • Infective endocarditis can initially present with just a fever.
  • However, the cutaneous manifestations of infective endocarditis include splinter haemorrhages in the nail beds, Osler nodes (painful nodules on pads of the fingers and toes caused by immune complex deposition), and Janeway lesions (Small, non-tender, erythematous macules on palms and soles)
  • This patient has erythema marginatum. Therefore, infective endocarditis is unlikely.

Option D: Heart Failure

  • Heart failure occurs secondary to a problem in the myocardium or a congenital cardiac defect causing pressure or volume overload on the normal myocardium.
  • The cutaneous manifestations of heart failure are nonspecific and include facial and pedal oedema.
  • This patient has no swelling or any other symptom suggesting heart failure. Therefore, heart failure is unlikely to occur in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is the appropriate precaution to be followed while recovering a bullet from the crime scene?

choices.text: Bullet should be cleaned with sterile water immediately
Bullet should be packed in leakproof packaging made of hard plastic
Bullet should be picked with metallic toothed forceps
Bullet should be removed with bare hands

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Bullet should be packed in leakproof packaging made of hard plastic:

  • The bullet should be packed in leakproof packaging made of hard plastic.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bullet should be cleaned with sterile water immediately: The bullet is gently rinsed only after collection of any trace evidence on the bullet (not immediately).

Option C - Bullet should be picked with metallic toothed forceps: To prevent marring of the bullet surface, it should be removed by a plastic forceps or a rubber tipped bullet extractor.

Option D - Bullet should be removed with bare hands: Bullets should be handled only by persons wearing double heavy-duty gloves.

questions.text: A 32-year-old at 37 weeks in labor with breech presentation. After an hour of oxytocin, the membranes rupture spontaneously. On vaginal examination, the umbilical cord is felt out of the cervix, which is 3 cm dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Augmentation of labor and expedited delivery
Fill the bladder retrograde and shift for emergency LSCS

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Fill the bladder retrograde and shift for emergency LSCS

  • It is a case of cord prolapse, an absolute indication of a lower section cesarian section since the prolapsed cord results in fetal anoxia and death in a very short period.
  • Filling the bladder retrograde (placing a catheter and instilling fluid into the bladder) helps create a cushion. It lifts the presenting part of the baby off the umbilical cord, reducing the risk of compression. Emergency cesarean section (LSCS) is then performed promptly to deliver the baby and relieve the pressure on the umbilical cord.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Augmentation of labor and expedited delivery

  • This option is not appropriate in the case of umbilical cord prolapse. Augmenting labor and proceeding with vaginal delivery can further compress the cord, leading to fetal distress and hypoxia.

Option B: Reposit the cord

  • This option involves attempting to gently push the prolapsed umbilical cord back into the uterus to relieve compression. However, repositioning the cord may not be successful or may lead to further complications, and the baby's condition can deteriorate rapidly.

Option D: Tocolysis

  • Tocolysis involves the use of medications to suppress uterine contractions. However, it is not the first-line treatment for umbilical cord prolapse. Immediate delivery is necessary to avoid compromising fetal blood flow, and tocolysis may delay the prompt delivery required in this emergency situation.

questions.text:
Match the following images with their names appropriately.


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			a. Chemoport
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. Nasogastric tube
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c. Malecot catheter
			
		
		
			
			4.
			
			
			d. Foley catheter
questions.solution:
Correct Option B 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A:

  • Malecot catheter: It is a reusable, self-retaining, radio-opaque catheter made of India rubber with a flower at the tip. The flower helps keep the catheter in place and prevents accidental removal.
    • Uses: Drainage of urine from bladder and kidneys, drainage of intraperitoneal collections, and as an intercostal drain.
  • Foley catheter: It is a common type of indwelling catheter made of latex. It is a self-retaining balloon catheter.
    • Uses: To measure urinary output, relieve urinary retention, and administer intravesicle chemotherapy.
  • Nasogastric tube: NG tubes are part of the standard of care in treating intestinal obstruction and can also be used to provide nutritional support. They are most common in surgical patients but are useful in any patient population where gastric decompression or nutritional support is necessary.
  • Chemoport: It is a totally implantable venous access device used for chemotherapy administration.

questions.text: Considering the National Leprosy Eradication Programme guidelines, what is the expected annual new case rate of leprosy per lakh of population?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 10 cases per lakh:

  • The National Leprosy Eradication Programme aims to reduce the annual new case rate of leprosy to less than 10 cases per lakh of population.
  • This initiative focuses on early detection and treatment to prevent the spread of the disease and its associated disabilities.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A,B and D are incorrect due to the above given reasons

questions.text: In the given plot, what does a diamond represent?

choices.text: The overall effect size of the studies
The publication status of the studies
The precision of the study results
The type of statistical analysis used

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The overall effect size of the studies:

  • In a blobbogram (forest plot), the diamond represents the overall effect size calculated from pooled estimates of individual study results, indicating the precision of findings. The vertical line at 0 denotes no effect.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C & D are incorrect.

  • Is not represented by the diamond in a forest plot.
